COMMIT: 8d942996ea2c9913ca4f8efe3a1ed07c8c638c42
DATE: 2023-11-10 15:47:01 -0600
MESSAGE: Stuff needed to make style work

Nobody _wants_ to be depressed. Or rather, people may act like they do, and even say that they do — in which case it is probably kindest to believe them — but the very deepest aspect of their mind simply _couldn't_ want such a thing if it could see clearly what it was choosing. A person may recognize this only after being free of it, and look back on it like a bizarre dream.

It wasn't until recently that empathy for depression became a social norm. Until then, contempt seemed to many like a perfectly healthy response, and sympathy was equated with coddling. Today, we know it's more nuanced: depending on the person and situation, either firmness or gentleness may be appropriate — but in neither case does an underlying attitude of contempt help anything.

Advances in neuroscience certainly helped drive this cultural shift, but were they really necessary? Once we knew that brains and genes were a thing, did we really need to know the exact details to feel empathy for the depressed? Did anyone ever doubt that it had _some_ physiological basis? Anyone "with the eyes to see" could directly perceive that contempt was the wrong approach. It served only to make the attacker feel superior, and it was harmful.

The same is true for alcoholism, addiction, obesity, and countless other conditions. It seems we have to re-learn the same lesson each time, using new science as justification — but it is always possible to see that the deepest aspect of our mind simply couldn't want to suffer. This "empathy shortcut" makes it clear that contempt makes zero sense in such situations. Our descendants will surely wonder how this wasn't obvious from the start.

What may be harder to see is that the base layer of our mind also doesn't want _others_ to suffer. People certainly act like they want this, and even sometimes say that they do — in which case it is dangerously naive not to believe them — but something surprisingly similar is going on beneath the surface. Their confused state is generated by a haze of profound delusion that will horrify them should they manage to break free of it. I do not have the neuroscience to prove this to you (yet), but it is plain for anyone with the eyes to see. It is not merely a belief.

Contempt for "bad people" makes zero sense for exactly the same reason as before: it merely compounds the delusion that's causing the problem to begin with. They are simply under the sway of a different form of mental illness. Our contempt doesn't exist to help anyone; it just helps us feel superior. The very deepest part of us knows this, but that knowledge somehow isn't reaching our conscious awareness.

Social norms have largely (and thankfully) robbed us of our ability to feel superior when treating mentally ill people (or mentally retarded people, or those with different skin color, ...) with contempt. People who do that are rightfully seen as wrong in the head themselves. But then we turn right around and treat _them_ with contempt — unable to see that we are repeating the same fundamental mistake.

If you don't yet have the "eyes to see" this, then it may sound hopelessly naive. But the truth is that the very deepest layer of your mind _cannot want to feel contempt for **anyone**_. If you could clearly see the choice you were making, you wouldn't make it. It is only tempting when in the grip of profound delusion. You may *say* that you want it, and deeply believe that it's helpful, but there will (hopefully) come a time when you are horrified by this confusion.

Just like you can't talk people out of depression, addiction, or evil, I can't talk you out of contempt[^talk-you-out]. Something must be _seen_.

---

Now, an important clarification: in the same way that we might need to be firm with someone with mental illness, we may need to be even more firm — perhaps even violent[^dalai-lama-gun] — with people who "want" to cause harm. Our response may even *look* like contempt. But *genuine* contempt comes from a completely different source; a deeply malicious one. They should not be confused.

It can be very hard to see how this change in motivation makes any difference. After all, violence is violence, right? But it's not. People are _ridiculously_ sensitive to our intentions, and malice generates very different long-term consequences than benevolence. This difference may not be obvious from the immediate (or even second- or third-order) effects, but again, it is visible to those with eyes to see.

When all desire for harm (for oneself and others) is eliminated from the mind, what remains isn't apathy or neutrality. Surprisingly, it is an impossibly fierce and uncompromising love for the world — one that is able to deal with all kinds of situations in a healthy way[^jesus].

My hope for humanity is that we discover this. I believe our very existence depends on it.

---


[^talk-you-out]: But I might as well try: stop feeling contempt, jackass. There, I bet that worked.

[^dalai-lama-gun]: The Dalai Lama was once asked what you should do if a gunman is trying to shoot you and you have a gun. [He said "shoot back."](https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/dalai-gun/)

[^jesus]: This is what guys like Jesus and Buddha realized (and many gals, too). They weren't suppressing the tendency for malice and contempt; they were simply free of the profound illness that enables them. I'm sure they didn't see themselves as "good people"; they were probably grateful to finally be mentally healthy. When we fancy ourselves virtuous for hating the "bad guys" in defense of the "good guys," we are desecrating the profound legacy they left us.

We like to believe that contempt for "bad people" is a sign of the good within us, but it's not: a healthy mind simply cannot feel contempt. But let's rewind this story a bit.

Consider depression. Nobody _wants_ to be depressed. Or rather, people may _act_ like they do, and even _say_ that they do — in which case it is probably kindest to believe them — but the very deepest aspect of their mind simply _couldn't_ want such a thing, if it could see clearly what it was choosing. A person may recognize this only after being free of it, and look back on it like a bizarre dream.

COMMIT: 0ab1d5889657d8d68f80e68b06f42d82ac75029c
DATE: 2023-11-11 11:08:17 -0600

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

It is easy to be kind to someone when we can see that they're trying. Otherwise, we have two options: find some part of them that _is_ trying and be kind to it, or else be unkind to their whole being. The latter is contempt, and it is lazy and harmful. There is literally _always_ a part that is trying.

Consider depression. Nobody _wants_ to be depressed. Or rather, people may _act_ like they do, and even _say_ that they do — in which case it is probably kindest to believe them — but the very deepest aspect of their mind simply _couldn't_ want such a thing, if it could see clearly what it was choosing. A person may recognize this only after being free of it, and look back on it like a bizarre dream.

It wasn't until recently that empathy for the depressed became a social norm. Until then, contempt seemed to many like a perfectly healthy response, and sympathy was equated with coddling. Today, we know better: depending on the person and situation, either firmness or gentleness may be appropriate, but in neither case does an underlying attitude of contempt help anything. The justification that "coddling is bad, so cruelty is good" is clearly self-serving nonsense: it is an excuse for our dark tendencies.

Advances in neuroscience certainly helped drive this cultural shift, but were they really necessary? Once we knew that brains and genes were a thing, did we really need to know the exact details to see that empathy was right? Did anyone ever doubt that depression had _some_ physiological basis? Anyone "with the eyes to see" could directly perceive that contempt was the wrong approach without waiting for proof.

The same is true for alcoholism, addiction, obesity, and countless other conditions. It seems we have to re-learn the same lesson each time, using new science as justification — even though it is always possible to see that the deepest aspect of people's minds simply couldn't want to suffer. This "empathy shortcut" makes it clear that contempt makes zero sense in such situations. "Tough love" may still be required, but it is still a form of love, not contempt — and the deepest aspect of *our* mind knows the difference. Our descendants will surely wonder how we ever overlooked it.

What may be harder to see is that this "base layer of mind" also doesn't want _others_ to suffer. People certainly act like they do, and even sometimes say that they do — in which case it is dangerously naive not to believe them — but something surprisingly similar is going on beneath the surface. Their confused state is generated by a haze of profound delusion that would horrify them should they manage to break free of it. I do not have the neuroscience to prove this to you (yet), but it is plain for anyone with the eyes to see. It is not merely a belief.

Contempt for "perpetrators" is bad for exactly the same reason as for "victims": it merely compounds the delusion that's causing the problem to begin with. It is a more cleverly disguised form of mental illness. The very deepest part of us knows this, but that knowledge somehow isn't reaching our conscious awareness.

Social norms have largely robbed us of our ability to feel superior when treating mentally ill people (or mentally retarded people, or those with different skin color, ...) with contempt. People who do that are rightfully seen as wrong in the head themselves. But then we turn right around and treat _them_ with contempt — unable to see that we are repeating the same fundamental mistake.

If you don't yet have "the eyes to see" this, then compassion for evildoers may sound hopelessly naive. But if so, then I contend that your mind is still under the grip of a powerful delusion. You may *say* that contempt is more helpful — and even believe it — but there will (hopefully) come a time when you are horrified by this confusion. The very deepest layer of your mind cannot want to feel contempt for **anyone**. If you could clearly see the choice you were making, you wouldn't make it.

Alas, just like we can't talk people out of depression, addiction, or evil, I can't talk you out of contempt[^talk-you-out]. There is something that must be _seen_.

---

Now, an important clarification must be made: in the same way that we might need to be firm with the mentally ill, we may need to be even more firm — perhaps even violent[^dalai-lama-gun] — with people who "want" to cause harm. Such a response may even *look* like contempt. But *genuine* contempt comes from a completely different source; a deeply malicious one. The two should not be confused[^confusion].

It can be very hard to see how this seemingly-subtle distinction could matter. After all, violence is violence, right? But it's not. People are _ridiculously_ sensitive to our intentions, and malice generates very different long-term consequences than benevolence. This difference may not be obvious from the immediate (or even second- or third-order) effects, but again, it is visible to those with eyes to see.

When all desire for harm (for oneself and others) is eliminated from the mind, what remains isn't apathy or neutrality. Surprisingly, it is an impossibly fierce and uncompromising love for the world — one that is able to deal with all kinds of situations in a healthy way[^jesus].

My hope for humanity is that we discover this. I believe that our very existence depends on it.

---

We know that being kind is the "right thing to do" in general, but things get hazy when it comes to "bad" people. Not only is it hard to be kind to them, but it's a bit unclear _why_ and even _whether_ we should. At the same time, there are many people who seem to be "bad" enough for this question to be directly relevant to us. They may not deserve our cruelty (yet), but they surely deserve our contempt. It feels like the _least_ we could do as decent people.

But what if there _is_ a sense in which kindness (properly defined) is _always_ the right thing to do, and our "innocent" deviation from it is responsible for tremendously more suffering than we realize?

This site is a collection of pieces exploring that theme.

- [Intro](intro.md)
- [The "evil conspiracy"](http://www.contemptisevil.org)
- [FAQ / glossary / notes](faq.md)

COMMIT: 92d3e09cc159170993f0db14683bd0149c575ed4
DATE: 2023-11-13 10:57:06 -0600
MESSAGE: Add defn of contempt to landing page; improve intro
================================


We know that being kind is the "right thing to do" in most situations, but things get hazy when it comes to "bad" people. Not only is it hard to be kind to them, but it's a bit unclear _why_ and even _whether_ we should. At the same time, there are many people who seem to be "bad" enough for this question to be relevant to us. They may not deserve our cruelty (yet), but they surely deserve our contempt. It feels like the _least_ we could do as decent people.

But what if there is a sense in which kindness (properly defined) is _always_ the right thing to do, and our "innocent" deviation from it is responsible for tremendously more suffering than we realize?

This site is a collection of pieces exploring that theme.

Contempt is hard to define, but here's a rough starting point: it's the feeling that someone is worthless or beneath consideration — often accompanied by a desire to make sure they know it. It is the sense that they are fundamentally defective (in the case of "bad people," fundamentally _morally_ defective). We generally want the best for people, even when they mess up. With contempt, this desire evaporates, and may even be replaced with malice. It often starts off much milder, with subtle feelings of suspicion and uncharitability. But these turn out to be self-reinforcing, as we shall see.

- [The "evil conspiracy"](http://www.contemptisevil.org)
- [FAQ / glossary / notes](faq.md)

COMMIT: f0633c200fa3d251940a0466059e8b31774eeb9e
DATE: 2023-11-14 09:44:58 -0600
MESSAGE: Improve home page
================================


We know that being kind is the "right thing to do" in most situations, but things get hazy when it comes to "bad" people. Not only is it hard to be kind to them, but it's a bit unclear _why_ and even _whether_ we should. At the same time, there are many people today who seem to be "bad" enough for this question to be relevant to us. They may not deserve our cruelty (yet), but they surely deserve our contempt. It feels like the _least_ we could do as decent people.

But what if there is a sense in which kindness (properly defined) is _always_ the right thing to do, and this "innocent" deviation from it is responsible for tremendously more suffering than we realize? 

This site is a collection of pieces exploring that theme.

---

Before we begin, what is contempt? It is easier to describe than define.

Imagine you are debating politics with someone whom you at first trust is well-intentioned. Slowly, as their position is revealed, you begin to doubt their intentions. Eventually, you become convinced that they could only believe these things if they were _fundamentally morally defective_.

It is this _fundamental-ness_ that is the defining characteristic of contempt, whether the defect itself is moral or not. Genocides are carried out when people believe their victims are _fundamentally_ sub-human[^genocide] (and not merely humans with "worse" religions or ethnicities). While our own contempt may not rise to the level of enabling atrocities — yet — it is a milder form of the same phenomenon. In this dark place, all goodwill is lost.

Mocking our political enemies is fun because we get to see them hurt, quite independently of whether the behavior is a net good — though of course we must tell ourselves that it is one. Our "victim" cannot be fixed, so it is only right to punish them — and what more humane way to punish someone than to subtly communicate, through our eyes and voice, how worthless they are? That is how it usually starts, but rarely how it ends.

The feeling can also be much more subtle and brief, as when we mutter "idiot" under our breath at a bad driver. But if left unchecked, this attitude becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy. Perhaps a part of us secretly _wants_ that...

- [The "evil conspiracy"](http://www.contemptisevil.org)
- [FAQ / glossary](faq.md)
- [Miscellaneous notes](misc.md)
- [Quotes](quotes.md)

[^genocide]: The Nazis referred to Jews as 'vermin' and during the genocide in Rwanda, Tutsis were referred to as 'cockroaches.' This is a common pattern throughout history.

COMMIT: 2c6739b6df57dd6fef17269ca52f1334eadbefcf
DATE: 2023-11-14 19:52:49 -0600
MESSAGE: Improve landing page
================================


We know that being kind is the "right thing to do" in most situations, but things get hazy when it comes to "bad" people. Not only is it hard to be kind to them, but it's a bit unclear _why_ and even _whether_ we should. At the same time, there are many people today who seem to be "bad" enough for this question to be relevant to us. They may not deserve our cruelty (yet), but they surely deserve our contempt. It feels like the _least_ we could do as decent people.

But what if there is a sense in which kindness (properly defined) is _always_ the right thing to do, and our "innocent" deviation from it is responsible for tremendously more suffering than we realize? 

This site is a collection of pieces exploring that theme.

---

Before we begin, what is contempt? It is easier to describe than define.

Consider how most of us seem to feel about our political opponents these days. They don't just have bad ideas; they seem _defective_ in some fundamental way. How else could they believe the ridiculous things they do (or claim to, anyway)? This _fundamental-ness_ is a defining characteristic of contempt; we are fundamentally better people than they are.

Genocides can only be carried out when people believe their victims are sub-human. It's not sufficient for them to be humans with "worse" religions or ethnicities; they must be something... _less_[^genocide]. While our own contempt may not rise to the level of enabling atrocities — yet — it is a milder form of the same phenomenon. 

In this dark place, all goodwill is lost. 

Mocking our political enemies is innocent fun, because we get to see bad people get hurt. This enjoyment is quite independent of whether our behavior somehow makes a positive difference in the world — though, of course, we must _tell_ ourselves that it does. Our "victim" cannot be fixed, so it is only right to punish them — and what more humane way than to subtly communicate, through our eyes and voice, how worthless they are? That is how it usually starts, but rarely how it ends.

The feeling can also be much more subtle and brief, as when we mutter "idiot" under our breath at a bad driver. But if left unchecked, this attitude becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy. And when _all_ of us are doing that, well... the result is bad, as we shall see.

---

Note that we make liberal use of the word "evil." This word should be understood in its most general sense, as the opposite of "good." We will examine its nature and causes.

We know that being kind is the "right thing to do" in most situations, but things get hazy when it comes to "bad" people. Not only is it hard to be kind to them, but it's a bit unclear _why_ and even _whether_ we should. At the same time, there are many people today who seem to be "bad" enough for this question to be relevant to us. They may not deserve our cruelty (yet), but they surely deserve our contempt. It feels like the _least_ we could do as decent people.

But what if there is a sense in which kindness (properly defined) is _always_ the right thing to do, and our "innocent" deviation from it is responsible for tremendously more suffering than we realize? 

This site is a collection of pieces exploring that question.

---

Before we begin, what is contempt? It is easier to describe than define.

Consider how most of us seem to feel about our political opponents these days. They don't just have bad ideas; they seem _defective_ in some fundamental way. How else could they believe the ridiculous things they do (or claim to, anyway)? This _fundamental-ness_ is a defining characteristic of contempt; we are fundamentally better people than they are.

Genocides can only be carried out when people believe their victims are sub-human. It's not sufficient for them to be humans with "worse" religions or ethnicities; they must be something... _less_[^genocide]. While our own contempt may not rise to the level of enabling atrocities — yet — it is a milder form of the same phenomenon. 

In this dark place, all goodwill is lost. 

Mocking our political enemies is "innocent" fun, because we get to see bad people get hurt. This enjoyment is quite independent of whether our behavior somehow makes a positive difference in the world — though, of course, we must _tell_ ourselves that it does. Our "victim" cannot be fixed, so it is only right to punish them — and what more humane way than to subtly communicate, through our eyes and voice, how worthless they are? That is how it usually starts, but rarely how it ends.

The feeling can also be much more subtle and brief, as when we mutter "idiot" under our breath at a bad driver, or even just suspicion and uncharitability toward a dialogue partner. But if left unchecked, this attitude becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy. And when _all_ of us are doing that, well... the result is bad, as we shall see.

---

Note that we make liberal use of the word "evil." This word should be understood in its most general sense, as the opposite of "good." We will examine its nature and causes.

- [Chapter 2: Self-deception](chapters/self-deception.md)
- [Chapter 3: The "evil conspiracy"](chapters/evil-conspiracy.md)
- [Chapter 4: The light at the end of the tunnel](chapters/the-light.md)

## Preface

COMMIT: 2b9f9903225b2e09065990f2cb6b907184f565e5
DATE: 2023-11-20 14:37:01 -0600
MESSAGE: Replace homepage
================================


> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

Contempt has become a popular attitude to take with those who we feel are responsible for the world's ills. It feels like a healthy way to affirm our values, communicate our anger, and deter others from similar misbehavior.

But contempt[^contempt] actually has a profoundly unhealthy origin and produces far-ranging toxic effects that are not only invisible to us, but are actually _hidden_ from us by our own minds. The aggregate result of everyone doing this is a world in which the problems we bemoan are all but inevitable.

This explains why the US is headed toward civil war while nobody recognizes their own complicity. The fault always seems to lie entirely with the other side, or perhaps with the evil elites who are playing both sides. Whatever their role, there is something going on within our own minds that we're not seeing.

It is imperative that we discover this trick by which our mind hides the true source and effects of our behavior — not only for our own sake, but the world's. When this is seen clearly, the problems of the world — and their solutions — begin to look radically different.

---

> _If only it were all so simple! If only there were evil people somewhere insidiously committing evil deeds, and it were necessary only to separate them from the rest of us and destroy them. But the line dividing good and evil cuts through the heart of every human being. And who is willing to destroy a piece of his own heart?_ —Alexander Solzhenitsyn

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light. So it is not strange that his ministers also masquerade as ministers of righteousness._ —2 Corinthians 11:14

We've all done something wrong while convincing ourselves that it's not. What we may not realize is that _all_ evil ultimately depends on this very mechanism of self-deception. We are motivated _not_ to see this, because that lets us believe that we are fundamentally different from the "bad people." We treat them with contempt to bait them into behaving in ways that confirm our moral superiority.

Unfortunately, baiting people into more evil is hardly "morally superior," so we must carefully hide our true motivation from ourselves. We call it "fighting evil." This is *itself* an act of self-deception — and perhaps the hardest one to detect, because it feels so righteously motivated. But seeing how your mind hides this truth is key to understanding how the "bad people" do what _they_ do without feeling bad.

Once you see this, everything changes.

You discover that there is darkness within each of us. It is not _intrinsic_ to our minds[^intrinsic], but is more like a parasite. It knows that we are only willing to harm people who we deem _subhuman_[^subhuman], so it does something very clever: it alters our perception such that we _see_ some people's darkness as intrinsic to their minds; we see them as _fundamentally_ bad in a way that we could never be. This way, we are free to be malicious without compunction.

Consciously, we don't realize that we're being manipulated by our darkness; it feels like we're expressing a natural and healthy instinct to violently attack evil — which we now equate with attacking _people_, since we can no longer distinguish the two. But no matter how subdued our attack (e.g., mockery), our underlying malicious intent makes us appear evil to them for exactly the same reason that they appear evil to us.

This has the effect of driving their darkness deeper into their minds, making it appear even _more_ obviously intrinsic, which licenses even more righteous violence from us, resulting in an all-too-familiar downward spiral. But the real shock is discovering that this mutual descent into Hell is secretly being orchestrated by the darkness in _both_ of our minds.

Our darkness tricks us into behaving in ways that it knows will convince others that we are evil, because it knows exactly how their darkness behaves — _because ours and theirs are fundamentally identical_. In fact, they are not just identical, but are more like outgrowths of a single shared "shadowy presence" that continually manipulates all of our minds; the _Devil_, if you will.

This is not just a wacky religious invention: it seems that everyone who introspects carefully enough eventually perceives this "distributed malevolent entity" with a kind of intelligence and volition of its own that, even if not _literally_ true, explain its seemingly-coordinated behavior terrifyingly well. _This_ is our true enemy; not other people (though fighting it sometimes requires fighting them). 

It is that primordial "evil global conspiracy" to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence. Every attempt to maliciously subdue it "out there" just strengthens it, because such behavior is only ever initiated _by_ it, even though it makes us believe that it was initiated by us. Contempt is its most insidious tool precisely because it appears to be the most unmistakably righteous. It is a secret way to leak evil deep into the world, where we can disown all complicity for it.

(To be clear: there may well be groups of particularly "bad" people who conspire to cause great harm, but their existence wouldn't be possible if the rest of us weren't feeding the source — and conversely, it is _inevitable_ given that we are. **We must hold such people accountable**, but when we do this with contempt, we are reinforcing the conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence.)

The only way for humanity to defeat the Devil is to stop falling for its tricks. _Any_ time you feel malice, contempt, or even self-righteousness toward another being; any time you see them as fundamentally defective or inferior; you are being manipulated into spreading evil in some way that you can't see. As you begin to clear up this misperception in your own mind, you discover more of what is causing it in others', which is the only way to do anything genuinely useful about it.

The topic of what such "useful" behavior looks like is vast and beyond the scope of this work, but rest assured that it _can_ be outwardly violent (or mocking) if the circumstances warrant it. It need not take any particular form, and cannot be reduced to principles, except for one: the more deeply it is rooted in compassion — that is, freedom from the above misperception — the more beneficial it tends to be. This is true kindness, and people can sense your profoundly benevolent intent even when you fight them. Being _entirely_ free is enlightenment; perception of our fundamental unity.

Enlightenment is a lofty goal, but we can start small, by changing social norms. And each of us understanding why _contempt is not the way_ seem like a good first step.

[^intrinsic]: You may wonder how it is possible to know that evil is not intrinsic to other people's minds, but for our purposes it's more important to see that (1) our _perception_ of their intrinsic defectiveness is our own projection, and (2) our own darkness gives us the capacity to devolve into a condition in which others would be utterly convinced that _ours_ is intrinsic.

[^subhuman]: Notice that genocides can only be perpetrated when the victims are seen as subhuman. The Nazis referred to Jews as 'vermin,' and during the genocide in Rwanda, Tutsis were referred to as 'cockroaches.' This is a common pattern throughout history.

_[Note: The author(s) of this piece are not Christian or even religious exactly, but there are so many good quotes and metaphors from the Bible and other traditions that we make extensive use of them.]_

---

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

We each have our own ideas about "what's wrong with the world," and who is responsible. When we think about them, we tend to feel contempt. This seems like a healthy way to affirm our values, convey our disapproval, and deter others from similar misbehavior. In other words, it helps us "fight evil" and save the world.

But what if it is a trap?

Contempt[^contempt] actually has a sinister origin, and produces far-ranging toxic effects that are not only invisible to us, but carefully _hidden_ from us by our own minds. It is not our friend: it fosters conditions in which the problems we bemoan are all but inevitable. At the micro level, this explains bitter divorces in which each side feels like the exclusive victim / hero; and at the macro level, why the US is headed toward civil war despite nobody recognizing their own complicity.

It is imperative that we discover this trick by which our mind hides the true source and effects of our behavior — not only for our own sake, but the world's. When it is fully unveiled, the problems of the world — and their solutions — begin to look radically different.

---

> _If only it were all so simple! If only there were evil people somewhere insidiously committing evil deeds, and it were necessary only to separate them from the rest of us and destroy them. But the line dividing good and evil cuts through the heart of every human being. And who is willing to destroy a piece of his own heart?_ —Alexander Solzhenitsyn

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light. So it is not strange that his ministers also masquerade as ministers of righteousness._ —2 Corinthians 11:14

We've all done something wrong while convincing ourselves that it isn't. What we may not realize is that _all_ evil ultimately depends on this very mechanism of self-deception. We are motivated _not_ to see this, because then we can believe that we are fundamentally different from the "bad people." _We treat them with contempt to bait them into behaving in ways that license more contempt, to reaffirm our moral superiority._

Unfortunately, such behavior is hardly "morally superior," so we must carefully hide this true motivation from ourselves. We label it "fighting evil," and calculate the ways in which it will actually help the world. This is *itself* an act of self-deception — and perhaps the hardest to detect, because it feels so righteously motivated. But seeing how our mind hides this truth is key to understanding how the "bad people" do what _they_ do without feeling bad.

Once you see this, everything changes.

> _How can you say to your brother, `Let me take the speck out of your eye,' when all the time there is a plank in your own eye? You hypocrite, first take the plank out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the speck from your brother's eye._ —Matthew 7:4

You discover that there is darkness within each of us. It is not _intrinsic_ to our minds[^intrinsic], but is more like a parasite. It knows that we are only willing to harm people who we deem _subhuman_[^subhuman], so it does something very clever: it alters our perception so that we see some people's darkness as intrinsic to their minds; we see them as _fundamentally_ bad, and therefore subhuman.

Consciously, we don't realize that we're being manipulated by our darkness; it feels like we're expressing a natural and healthy instinct to violently attack evil — which we now equate with attacking _people_, since we can no longer distinguish the two. But no matter how subdued our attack (e.g., mockery), our underlying malicious intent makes _us_ appear evil to them for exactly the same reason that they appear evil to us.

This has the effect of driving their darkness deeper into their minds, making them appear even more "fundamentally" bad, which licenses even more righteous violence from us, resulting in an all-too-familiar downward spiral. But the real shock is discovering that this mutual descent into Hell is secretly being orchestrated by the darkness in _both_ of our minds.

Our darkness tricks us into behaving in ways that it knows will convince others that we are evil, because it knows exactly how their darkness will respond — _because ours and theirs are fundamentally identical_. In fact, they are not just identical, but are more like outgrowths of a single shared "shadowy presence" that continually manipulates all of our minds; the _Devil_, if you will.

This is not just a wacky religious invention: it seems that everyone who introspects carefully enough eventually perceives this "distributed malevolent entity" with a seeming intelligence and volition of its own that, even if not _literally_ true, explain its apparently-coordinated behavior terrifyingly well. 

It is that primordial "evil global conspiracy" to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence. Every attempt to maliciously subdue it "out there" just strengthens it, because such behavior is only ever initiated _by_ it, even though it makes us believe that it was initiated by us. Contempt is its most insidious tool precisely because it appears to be the most unmistakably righteous. It is a secret way to leak evil deep into the world, where we can disown all complicity for it.

(To be clear: there may well be groups of particularly "bad" people who conspire to cause great harm, but their existence wouldn't be possible if the rest of us weren't feeding the source — and conversely, it is _inevitable_ given that we are. **We must hold such people accountable**, but when we do this with contempt, we are reinforcing the conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence.)

Our true enemy is not other people, but the parasite in all of our minds. Contempt is nothing but a way to hide that fact from ourselves.

The only way for humanity to defeat the "Devil" is to stop falling for its tricks. _Any_ time you feel malice, contempt, or even self-righteousness toward another being; any time you see them as fundamentally defective or inferior; you are being manipulated into spreading evil in some way that you can't yet see. As you begin to clear up this misperception in your own mind, you discover more of what is causing it in others', which is the only way to do anything genuinely useful about it.

The topic of what such "useful" behavior looks like is vast and beyond the scope of this work, but rest assured that it _can_ be outwardly violent (or mocking) if the circumstances warrant it. It need not take any particular form, and cannot be reduced to principles, except for one: the more deeply it is rooted in compassion — that is, freedom from the above misperception — the more beneficial it tends to be[^compassion]. Being _entirely_ free is enlightenment; perception of our fundamental unity.

Enlightenment is a lofty goal, but we can start small, by changing social norms. Understanding why _contempt is not the way_ seems like a good first step.

[^subhuman]: Notice that genocides can only be perpetrated when the victims are seen as subhuman. The Nazis referred to Jews as 'vermin,' and during the genocide in Rwanda, Tutsis were referred to as 'cockroaches.' This is a common pattern throughout history.

_[Note: The author(s) of this piece are not Christian or even religious exactly, but there are so many good quotes and metaphors from the Bible and other traditions that we make extensive use of them.]_

---

We each have our own ideas about "what's wrong with the world," and who is responsible. When we think about them, we tend to feel contempt. This seems like a healthy way to affirm our values, convey our disapproval, and deter others from similar misbehavior. In other words, it helps us "fight evil" and save the world.

But what if it is a trap?

Contempt[^contempt] actually has a sinister origin, and produces far-ranging toxic effects that are not only invisible to us, but carefully _hidden_ from us by our own minds. It is not our friend: it fosters the very conditions in which the problems we bemoan are all but inevitable. At the micro level, it results in bitter divorces in which each side feels like the exclusive victim / hero; and at the macro level, it explains why the US is headed toward civil war despite nobody recognizing their own complicity.

It is imperative that we discover this trick by which our mind hides the true source and effects of our behavior — not only for our own sake, but the world's. When it is fully unveiled, the problems of the world — and their solutions — begin to look radically different.

---

> _If only it were all so simple! If only there were evil people somewhere insidiously committing evil deeds, and it were necessary only to separate them from the rest of us and destroy them. But the line dividing good and evil cuts through the heart of every human being._ —Alexander Solzhenitsyn

_tl;dr: The purpose of contempt is to bait people into behavior that confirms our superiority and licenses even more contempt._

Imagine giving someone a dehumanizing stare. It's hard to do, isn't it? It feels evil — because it is. Now imagine that this someone is a "bad person." The worse they are, the more righteous it will feel. Yet it will never look any less evil to them — _because it's not._ And unless they are a saint (which they're not), this will only make them feel _more_ justified in whatever storyline is fueling their misbehavior — because they can now plausibly claim that they are opposing evil.  You will in turn take this as confirmation that _they_ really are evil, and ramp up your dehumanization.

This will result in an all-too-familiar downward spiral. But the big shock is discovering that this is all being orchestrated by a dark aspect within both of your minds. Yours baited theirs, and vice versa. This can all be done subconsciously, through the eyes and tone of voice — no physical violence necessary.

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light._ —2 Corinthians 11:14

You know the classic image of the angel and devil sitting on our shoulders? It's _almost_ accurate, except for two things. First, the angel isn't really external to you, but represents the deepest aspect of your mind. In a profound sense, it *is* you. The devil is external; a kind of parasite[^intrinsic]. But it doesn't just whisper obviously-bad ideas in your ear; it alters your very perception such that evil feels unmistakably righteous. It pretends to _be_ you / your angel. If it does its job well, you won't even feel like you _have_ a devil — at least, not in the way that _bad_ people do.

One of its tricks is to make other people appear subhuman, so that harming them feels okay[^subhuman]. Your morals (and social norms) act as a kind of buffer, so that it can't do this openly with most people. But it's always on the hunt for victims, and it only needs the slightest provocation to begin its manipulation.

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

It searches for people whose misbehavior can't be chalked up to a "great battle." Your angel knows that if you look deeply enough, you will _always_ find a kind of battle — and that even though this won't condone their sins, it will prevent you from hating them. So your devil does something clever: it makes you perceive their devil as _intrinsic_ to their minds. You will then see them as _fundamentally defective_ — and therefore subhuman. There is no need to look for any "battle."

This is the wedge it uses to prevent your angel from getting a solid grip. And the nature of _their_ devil is such that you will both rapidly accelerate away from any possibility of mutual humanizing. Both yours and theirs _knew_ this would happen, because they are fundamentally identical. In fact, not only are they identical, but with enough subtlety of perception, you may notice that they act more like puppets of a single _shared_ Devil that is currently flowing freely through humanity.

This is not just a wacky religious invention: it seems that everyone who introspects carefully enough eventually perceives this "distributed malevolent entity" with a seeming intelligence and volition of its own that, even if not _literally_ true, explain its apparently-coordinated behavior terrifyingly well. Your interaction isn't limited to the two of you: it ripples out from each of you into your lives, eventually reaching the far corners of the world.

It is that primordial "evil global conspiracy" to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence. Every attempt to maliciously subdue it "out there" just strengthens it, because such behavior is only ever initiated _by_ it, even though it makes us believe that it was initiated by us. Contempt is its most insidious tool precisely because it appears to be the most unmistakably righteous. It is a secret way to leak evil deep into the world, where we can disown all complicity for it.

(To be clear: there may well be groups of particularly "bad" people who conspire to cause great harm, but their existence wouldn't be possible if the rest of us weren't feeding the source — and conversely, it is _inevitable_ given that we are. **We must hold such people accountable**, but when we do this with contempt, we are reinforcing the conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence.)

Our true enemy is not other people, but the parasite manipulating _all_ of our minds. The greatest gift you can give the world is returning to your "angel"; the only thing that can truly evict the "devil." This "angel" is not weak, and it's not always nice. It can do whatever is required to defeat evil. The only thing it never does is fall into that dark state of mind where it _pretends_ to be doing good while secretly causing mayhem.

_Any_ time you feel malice, contempt, or even self-righteousness toward another being; any time you see them as fundamentally defective or inferior; you are being manipulated into spreading evil in some way that you can't yet see. It is only by clearing up this misperception in your own mind that you begin to see what is causing it in others' — and thereby become able to do something genuinely useful about it.

This is called compassion[^compassion]. It doesn't always know what the most beneficial behavior is. That requires _wisdom_. It only ensures that you are, indeed, behaving in a way that is truly aligned with your deepest values; your profound love for the world. Developing wisdom is a vast topic, and beyond the scope of this work.

When compassion is developed to its full extent, it reveals the vast interconnectedness not only of humanity, but of all of reality. From here, malice and contempt are literally impossible. This is something that is only fully seen upon enlightenment — but we can all sense it to a greater or lesser degree at all times. 

Enlightenment is a lofty goal, but we can start small, by changing social norms. Contempt for "bad people" is the most insidious, and must go the way of all other forms of hatred if we are to survive.

## Footnotes

[^contempt]: Specifically, it is contempt for *people* that is wrong. Contempt for ideas or behaviors can actually be healthy.

[^intrinsic]: You may wonder how it is possible to know that evil is not intrinsic to other people's minds, but for our purposes it's more important to see that (1) our _perception_ of their intrinsic defectiveness is our own projection, and (2) our own darkness gives us the capacity to devolve into a condition in which others would be utterly convinced that _ours_ is intrinsic.

[^subhuman]: Notice that genocides can only be perpetrated when the victims are seen as subhuman. The Nazis referred to Jews as 'vermin,' and during the genocide in Rwanda, Tutsis were referred to as 'cockroaches.' This is a common pattern throughout history.

[^compassion]: You could say that everything comes down to distinguishing when we're being malicious in the name of good vs compassionate in a way that necessitates harm. People can sense the difference, even when we think they can't.


================================
COMMIT: 265fcbb973e2144f53bfe84a137ea349b5db80b2
DATE: 2023-11-23 11:24:47 -0600
MESSAGE: Add image for open graph
================================

---
image: /img/no-contempt.png
---

_[Note: The author(s) of this piece are not Christian or even religious exactly, but there are so many good quotes and metaphors from the Bible and other traditions that we make extensive use of them.]_

---

We each have our own ideas about "what's wrong with the world," and who is responsible. When we think about them, we tend to feel contempt. It seems like a healthy way to affirm our values, convey our disapproval, and deter others from similar misbehavior — in other words, it helps us "fight evil" and save the world.

But what if it is a trap?

Contempt[^contempt] actually has a sinister origin, and produces far-ranging toxic effects that are not only invisible to us, but carefully _hidden_ from us by our own minds. It fosters the very conditions in which the problems we decry are all but inevitable. At the micro level, it results in bitter divorces in which each side feels like the exclusive victim / hero; and at the macro level, it explains why the US is headed toward civil war despite nobody recognizing their own complicity. On an even greater scale, it explains that archetypal "evil global conspiracy" that captures our imagination.

It is imperative that we discover this trick by which our mind hides the true source and effects of our behavior — not only for our own sake, but the world's. When it is fully unveiled, the problems of the world — and their solutions — begin to look radically different.

---

_tl;dr: The purpose of contempt is to bait people into behavior that licenses even more contempt. We do this to reassure ourselves that evil doesn't exist in our own minds, but only other people's. The result is a world in which "evil forces" seemingly conspire against us, and we never suspect the truth: that we've always been in on the conspiracy. The central tools we use to fight it — contempt, malice, etc. — are precisely what empower it._

> _If only it were all so simple! If only there were evil people somewhere insidiously committing evil deeds, and it were necessary only to separate them from the rest of us and destroy them. But the line dividing good and evil cuts through the heart of every human being._ —Alexander Solzhenitsyn

Imagine giving someone a dehumanizing stare. It's hard to do, isn't it? It feels evil — because it is. Now imagine that this someone is a "bad person." The worse they are, the more righteous it will feel. Yet it will never look any less evil to them — _because it's not._ And unless they are a saint (which they're not), this will only make them feel _more_ justified in whatever storyline is fueling their misbehavior — because they can now plausibly claim that they are opposing evil.  You will in turn take this as confirmation that _they_ really are evil and ramp up your dehumanization.

The world will now rapidly become darker, in an all-too-familiar downward spiral. But the big shock is discovering that this was all orchestrated by a dark aspect within _both_ of your minds: yours baited theirs, and vice versa. This didn't even require physical violence; it could all be done subconsciously, through the eyes and tone of voice.

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light._ —2 Corinthians 11:14

You know the classic image of the angel and devil sitting on our shoulders? It's _almost_ accurate, except for two things. First, the angel isn't really external to you, but represents the deepest aspect of your mind; your profound love for the world. In a deep sense, it *is* you. The devil is external; a kind of parasite[^intrinsic]. But it doesn't just whisper obviously-bad ideas in your ear; it pretends to *be* you, and alters your very perception so that certain evils appear unerringly righteous. The more successful it is, the less you will believe that you even have one — at least, in the same way that "bad people" do.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="33%" src="img/parasite.png "> 
</p>

One of its tricks is to make some people appear subhuman, so that harming them feels okay[^subhuman]. Your morals (and social norms) act as a kind of buffer, preventing you from seeing most people this way. But it's always on the hunt for victims, and it only needs the slightest provocation to begin its manipulation.

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

It searches for people whose misbehavior can't be chalked up to any kind of "great battle." Your angel knows that if you look deeply enough, you will _always_ find a kind of battle — and that this will prevent you from hating them, even if you must fight them. So your devil does something clever: it makes you perceive their devil as _intrinsic_ to their minds. You will then see them as _fundamentally bad_ or _defective_ — and therefore subhuman.

This is the wedge it uses to prevent your angel from getting an empathetic grip. This triggers behavior that will cause you both to rapidly accelerate away from any possibility of mutual humanizing. Both your devil and theirs and theirs _knew_ this would happen, because they are fundamentally identical. In fact, not only are they identical, but in a certain sense they behave more like puppets of a single shared Devil that is pulling _all_ of our strings.

This is not just a religious invention: it seems that everyone who introspects carefully enough eventually perceives this "distributed malevolent entity" with a seeming intelligence and volition of its own that, even if not _literally_ true, explain its apparently-coordinated behavior terrifyingly well. Your interaction isn't limited to the two of you: it ripples out from each of you into your lives, eventually reaching the far corners of the world.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="33%" src="img/shared-devil.png "> 
</p>

It is that primordial "evil global conspiracy;" the one to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence. Every attempt to maliciously subdue it "out there" just strengthens it, because such behavior is only ever initiated _by_ it — though it makes us believe it was our (righteous) idea. Contempt is a form of self-deception, and like all others, it secretly invites more self-deception in others. It opens up that shadowy space of mind in which evil can be "safely" committed. This ripples out to the far corners of the globe, where we can plausibly deny any connection to it.

To be clear: there may well be groups of particularly "bad" people who conspire to cause great harm, but their existence wouldn't be possible if the rest of us weren't feeding the source — and conversely, it is _inevitable_ given that we are. **We must hold such people accountable** — but when we do this with contempt, we are reinforcing the conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence.

Our true enemy is not other people, but the parasite manipulating _all_ of our minds. The greatest gift you can give the world is healing yourself of it. This returns you to your "angel"; the only thing that can truly evict anyone's "devil." This "angel" is not weak, and it's not always nice. It can do whatever is required to defeat evil. The only thing it never does is lead you into that illusion from which you _pretend_ to be doing good while secretly causing mayhem.

_Any_ time you feel malice, contempt, or even self-righteousness toward another being; any time you see them as fundamentally defective or inferior; you are being manipulated into spreading evil in some way that you can't yet see. It is only by clearing up this misperception in your own mind that you begin to see what is causing it in others' — and thereby become able to do anything genuinely useful about it.

This is called compassion[^compassion]. It doesn't always know what the most beneficial behavior is. That requires _wisdom_. It only ensures that you are, indeed, behaving in a way that is aligned with your deepest values; your profound love for the world. Developing wisdom is a vast topic, and beyond the scope of this work.

When compassion is developed to its full extent, it reveals the vast interconnectedness not only of humanity, but of all of reality. From here, malice and contempt are literally impossible. This is something that is only fully seen upon enlightenment — but [we can all sense it](unity.md) to a greater or lesser degree at all times. 

Enlightenment is a lofty goal, but we can start small, by changing social norms. We can teach our children (and remind our allies) that contempt for "bad people" isn't at all what it seems to be. It must go the way of all other forms of evil if we are to defeat our true enemy.

---

---
image: https://www.nomorecontempt.org/img/no-contempt-black.png
---

_[Note: The author(s) of this piece are not Christian or even religious exactly, but there are so many good quotes and metaphors from the Bible and other traditions that we couldn't help but make extensive use of them.]_

---

We each have our own ideas about "what's wrong with the world," and who is responsible. When we think about them, we tend to feel contempt. It seems like a healthy way to affirm our values, convey our disapproval, and deter others from similar misbehavior — in other words, it helps us "fight evil" and save the world.

But what if it is a trap?

Contempt[^contempt] actually has a sinister origin, and produces far-ranging toxic effects that are not only invisible to us, but carefully _hidden_ from us by our own minds. It fosters the very conditions in which the problems we decry are all but inevitable. At the micro level, it results in bitter divorces in which each side feels like the exclusive victim / hero; and at the macro level, it explains why the US is headed toward civil war despite nobody recognizing their own complicity. On an even greater scale, it begins to look like that archetypal "evil global conspiracy" that captures our collective imagination.

It is imperative that we discover this trick by which our mind hides the true source and effects of our behavior — not only for our own sake, but the world's. When it is fully unveiled, the problems of the world — and their solutions — begin to look radically different.

---

_tl;dr: The purpose of contempt is to bait people into behavior that licenses even more contempt. We do this to reassure ourselves that evil doesn't exist in our own minds, but only other people's. The result is a world in which "evil forces" seemingly conspire against us, while we never suspect the truth: that we've always been in on the conspiracy. The central tools we use to fight it — contempt, malice, etc. — are precisely what empower it._

> _If only it were all so simple! If only there were evil people somewhere insidiously committing evil deeds, and it were necessary only to separate them from the rest of us and destroy them. But the line dividing good and evil cuts through the heart of every human being._ —Alexander Solzhenitsyn

Imagine giving someone a dehumanizing stare. It's hard to do, isn't it? It feels evil — because it is. Now imagine that this someone is a "bad person." The worse they are, the more righteous it will feel. Yet it will never look any less evil to them — _because it's not._ And unless they are a saint (which they're not), this will only make them feel _more_ justified in whatever storyline is fueling their misbehavior — because they can now plausibly claim that they are opposing evil.  You will in turn take this as confirmation that _they_ really are evil and intensify your dehumanization.

The world will rapidly become darker, resulting in an all-too-familiar downward spiral. But the big shock is discovering that this was all orchestrated by a dark aspect within _both_ of your minds: yours baited theirs, and vice versa. It didn't even require physical violence; it could all be accomplished subconsciously, through the eyes and tone of voice.

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light._ —2 Corinthians 11:14

You know the classic image of the angel and devil sitting on our shoulders? It's _almost_ accurate, except for two things. First, the angel isn't really external to you, but represents the deepest aspect of your mind; your profound love for the world. In a deep sense, it *is* you. The devil is external; a kind of parasite[^intrinsic]. But it doesn't just whisper obviously-bad ideas in your ear; it pretends to be your inner angel, and alters your very perception so that certain evils appear unerringly righteous. The more successful it is, the less you will believe that you even _have_ a devil — at least, in the same way that "bad people" do.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="33%" src="img/parasite.png "> 
</p>

One of its tricks is to make some people appear subhuman, so that harming them feels okay[^subhuman]. Your morals (and social norms) act as a kind of buffer, preventing you from seeing most people this way. But it's always on the hunt for victims, and it only needs the slightest excuse to begin its manipulation.

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

It searches for people whose misbehavior can't be chalked up to any kind of "great battle." Your angel knows that if you look deeply enough, you will _always_ find a kind of battle — and that this will prevent you from hating them, even if you must fight them. So your devil does something clever: it makes you perceive their devil as _intrinsic_ to their minds. You will then see them as _fundamentally bad_ or _defective_ — and therefore subhuman and worthy of harm.

This is the wedge it drives to prevent your angel from getting an empathetic grip. It triggers behavior that will cause you both to rapidly accelerate away from any possibility of mutual humanizing. Both your devil and theirs and theirs _knew_ this would happen, because they are fundamentally identical. In fact, not only are they identical, but from a certain perspective they behave more like puppets of a single shared Devil that is pulling _all_ of our strings.

This is not just a religious invention: it seems that everyone who introspects carefully enough eventually perceives this "distributed malevolent entity" with a seeming intelligence and volition of its own that, even if not _literally_ true, explain its apparently-coordinated behavior terrifyingly well. Your interaction with the "bad person" ripples out from each of you into your lives, eventually reaching the far corners of the world — where you can plausibly deny any connection to it.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="33%" src="img/shared-devil.png "> 
</p>

It is that primordial "evil global conspiracy;" the one to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence. Every attempt to maliciously subdue it "out there" just strengthens it, because such behavior is only ever initiated _by_ it — though it makes us believe it was our (righteous) idea. Contempt is a form of self-deception, and like all others, it secretly invites more self-deception in others. It invites others into that shadowy space of mind in which evil can be "safely" committed.

To be clear: there may well be groups of particularly "bad" people who conspire to cause great harm, but their existence wouldn't be possible if vast numbers of us weren't continually feeding the source — and conversely, it is _inevitable_ given that we are. **We must hold such people accountable** — but when we do this with contempt, we are reinforcing the conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence.

_Any_ time you feel malice, contempt, or even self-righteousness toward another being; any time you see them as fundamentally defective or inferior; you are being tricked into spreading evil in some way that you can't yet see. Your true enemy isn't other people, but the parasite manipulating _all_ of our minds. The greatest gift you can give the world is healing yourself of it. The more this infection clears up, the more you see how it infects other minds, and the more you can do about it.

This brings you closer to your "angel"; the only thing that can truly evict anyone's "devil." It is not weak, and it's not always nice. It can take any form needed to defeat evil, including violence[^dalai-lama-gun] and even _apparent_ contempt. The one thing it never does is lead you into that illusion from which you _pretend_ to be doing good while secretly causing mayhem.

This is also called compassion[^compassion]. It doesn't always know what the most beneficial behavior is. That requires _wisdom_. Developing wisdom is a vast topic, and beyond the scope of this work. Compassion simply ensures that you are, indeed, behaving in a way that is aligned with your deepest values; your profound love for the world. People can sense your underlying motivation even when you think they can't, and it makes more difference than you can fathom.

This is why wise people urge compassion for evildoers. They aren't suggesting that we be _nice._ They're warning us that the only alternative is being (and spreading) evil in the name of good. The first time you discover this in yourself, you will be brought to your knees in abject agony over the horror that you've been inadvertently been perpetrating on the world.

The more compassion is unveiled, the more it reveals the vast interconnectedness not only of humanity, but of all of reality. This is fully revealed only upon enlightenment — though [we can all sense it](unity.md) to a greater or lesser degree at all times. From here, malice and contempt are literally impossible. The better you understand people's confused minds, the less you can hate them.

Enlightenment is a lofty goal, but we can start small, by changing social norms. We can teach our children (and remind our allies) that contempt for "bad people" isn't what it seems to be. It must go the way of all other forms of evil if we are to defeat our true enemy.

---

We each have our own ideas about "what's wrong with the world," and who is responsible. When we think about them, we tend to feel contempt. It seems like a healthy way to affirm our values, convey our disapproval, and deter others from similar misbehavior — in other words, to help us "fight evil" and save the world.

But what if it is a trap?

Contempt[^contempt] actually has a sinister origin, and produces far-ranging toxic effects that are not only invisible to us, but carefully _hidden_ from us by our own minds. It fosters the very conditions in which the problems we decry are all but inevitable. At the micro level, it results in bitter divorces in which each side feels like the exclusive victim / hero; and at the macro level, it explains why the US is headed toward civil war despite nobody recognizing their own complicity. On an even greater scale, it begins to look like that archetypal "evil global conspiracy" that captures our collective imagination.

It is imperative that we discover this trick by which our mind hides the true source and effects of our behavior — not only for our own sake, but the world's. When it is fully unveiled, the problems of the world — and their solutions — begin to look radically different.

## Radical kindness

When wise people urge compassion for evildoers, they're not suggesting that we be _nice._ They're warning us that the only other option is to be — and spread — _evil_.

Think of compassion and malice as existing on opposite ends of a spectrum. Compassion is our profound love for the world, and can manifest as being pleasant and agreeable (i.e., _nice_), or fierce and even violent, depending on the situation. Malice cares only about causing harm, though it often uses "the greater good" as justification — especially if we fancy ourselves "good people."

The two arise from very different aspects of the mind, but it can be extremely hard to tell them apart: are we harming this person in the genuine service of good, or only in the _name_ of good? Is it an expression of our love, or of our darkest tendencies _masquerading_ as love? Does our intention even matter? After all, harm is harm, right?

No, it's not — and this confusion is precisely what enables evil to creep into the world undetected.

People are _ridiculously_ sensitive to our motivations, and malice makes us appear subtly (or not-so-subtly) evil to them. This triggers exactly the same reaction in "bad people" that their apparent evil does in us: it evokes malice, which makes them look even _more_ evil to us, leading to a downward spiral into Hell. It doesn't require physical violence; it can be kicked off by a dehumanizing gaze.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/half-evil.png"> 
</p>

Malicious intent makes us look evil because it _is_: it is secretly designed to darken the world while giving us plausible deniability. We were only "fighting evil" — and how could that ever be wrong? We don't even have to be talking _to_ our target: simply by talking _about_ them with malice, we are inducing hatred in the world in the name of good.

If we could see how dark this really is, we would be unable to do it. It is only possible because we carefully hide the full extent of the _wrongness_ from ourselves. But such self-deception is precisely how "bad people" are able to do what _they_ do: part of them knows perfectly well that what they are doing is wrong, but that _wrongness_ is cleverly hidden from conscious self-reflection.

It is this shadowy state of mind that ultimately enables _all_ evil. If we (the "good people") can't see how easily we are seduced by it, how do we expect them (the "bad people") to? The truth is, we don't.

Our self-image prevents us from admitting that we have anything in common with them, and so instead of recognizing their behavior as self-deceptive — which could actually help them and the world — we perceive them as _fundamentally defective_, so that we can behave maliciously, thus doing our part to keep them trapped in their delusion.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/devil-vs-devil.png"> 
</p>

In other words, our very identity as one of the (precious few) "good people" battling the hordes of evil ensures that we subconsciously behave in ways that keep that battle alive. It doesn't even require seeing people as "evil": simply by feeling malice, hatred, contempt, or even self-righteousness, our minds are cleverly plotting a way to darken the world for our (supposed) benefit.

We _must_ stop doing this.

---

## Angels and Devils

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light._ —2 Corinthians 11:14

You know the classic image of the angel and devil sitting on our shoulders? It's _almost_ accurate, except for two things. First, the angel isn't really external to you, but represents the deepest aspect of your mind; your fundamentally compassionate nature. In a deep sense, it *is* you. The devil is external; a kind of parasite[^intrinsic]. But it doesn't just whisper obviously-bad ideas in your ear; it pretends to be your inner angel, and alters your very perception so that certain evils appear unerringly righteous.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/parasite.png"> 
</p>

One of its tricks is to make people appear subhuman, so that harming them feels okay[^subhuman]. Your morals (and social norms) act as a kind of buffer, preventing you from seeing most people this way. But it's always on the hunt for victims, and it only needs the slightest excuse to begin its manipulation.

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

It searches for people whose misbehavior can't be chalked up to any kind of "great battle" — the "bad people." Your angel knows that if you look deeply enough, you will _always_ find a kind of battle — and that this will prevent you from hating them, even if you must fiercely fight them. So your devil does something clever: it makes you perceive their devil as _intrinsic_ to their minds. You will then see them as _fundamentally bad_ or _defective_ — and therefore subhuman and worthy of harm.

This is the wedge it drives to prevent your angel from getting an empathetic grip. It triggers behavior that will cause you both to rapidly accelerate away from any possibility of mutual humanizing. Both your devil and theirs _knew_ this would happen, because they are fundamentally identical. In fact, not only are they identical, but from a certain perspective they behave more like puppets of a single shared Devil that is pulling _all_ of our strings.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/shared-devil.png"> 
</p>

This is not just a religious invention: it seems that everyone who introspects carefully enough eventually perceives this "distributed malevolent entity" with a seeming intelligence and volition of its own that, even if not _literally_ true, explain its apparently-coordinated behavior terrifyingly well. Your interaction with the "bad person" ripples out from each of you into your lives, eventually reaching the far corners of the world — where you can plausibly deny any connection to it.

---

## An "evil conspiracy"

This is that primordial "evil global conspiracy"; the one to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence — and _we_ are its secret minions. It isn't being run by a group of people; it lives in *all* of our minds. Every attempt to maliciously subdue it "out there" just strengthens it, because such behavior is only ever initiated _by_ it — though it makes us believe it was our (righteous) idea.

To be clear: there may well be groups of particularly "bad" people who conspire to cause great harm, but their existence wouldn't be possible if vast numbers of us weren't continually tilling the soil of self-deception — and conversely, it is _inevitable_ given that we are. **We must hold such people accountable** — but when we do this with contempt, we are reinforcing the conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence. (And, horrible as it is to admit, something in our minds is doing this _on purpose_, so that we always have someone to point our fingers at.)

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/evil-conspiracy.png"> 
</p>

_Any_ time you feel malice, contempt, or self-righteousness toward another being; any time you see them as fundamentally defective or inferior; you are being tricked into spreading evil in some way that you can't yet see. These are all forms of self-deception, and secretly invite more self-deception in others — that shadowy space of mind in which evil can be "safely" committed.

Your true enemy isn't other people, but the parasite manipulating _all_ of our minds. The greatest gift you can give the world is healing yourself of it. The more this infection clears up, the more you see how it infects other minds, and the more you can do about it.

This brings you closer to your "angel"; the only thing that can truly evict anyone's "devil." It is not weak, and it's not always nice. It can take any form needed to defeat evil, including violence[^dalai-lama-gun] and even _apparent_ contempt. The one thing it never does is lead you into that illusion from which you _pretend_ to be doing good while secretly causing mayhem.

This is also called compassion. It doesn't always know what the most beneficial behavior is. That requires _wisdom_. Developing wisdom is a vast topic, and beyond the scope of this work. Compassion simply ensures that you are, indeed, behaving in a way that is aligned with your deepest values; your profound love for the world. People can sense your underlying motivation even when you think they can't, and it makes more difference than you can fathom.

The first time you see this, you will be brought to your knees in abject agony over the horror that you've been inadvertently been perpetrating on the world — especially as you discover that part of you has _always_ known what you've really been doing.

The more compassion is unveiled, the more it reveals the vast interconnectedness not only of humanity, but of all of reality. This is fully revealed only upon enlightenment — though [we can all sense it](unity.md) to a greater or lesser degree at all times. From here, malice and contempt are literally impossible. The better you understand people's confused minds, the less you can hate them.

Enlightenment is a lofty goal, but we can start small, by changing social norms. We can teach our children (and remind our allies) that contempt for "bad people" isn't what it seems to be. It must go the way of all other forms of evil if we are to defeat our true enemy.

## Notes

*It is surely the case that some people are so far gone that our fledgling attempts to be compassionate can backfire. This is a deep and difficult issue, and beyond the scope of this piece.*
