Why is it so hard to maintain our humanity in the face of evil? And why are we "supposed to" in the first place?

---

All misbehavior — from cutting in line to genuine atrocities — is ultimately enabled by a kind of parasite in the mind. Think of it as that devil on our shoulders. It doesn't just whisper obviously-evil ideas in our ears; no, it alters our very perception, so that it appears okay (or even _righteous_) to step on certain people. It shields us from confronting the full implications of our words and behaviors.

The "bad people" know perfectly well when what they are doing is wrong, but that knowledge is very cleverly hidden from conscious self-reflection. If you try to viciously force them to confront it, it just drives the parasite deeper into their minds. But something in you already knows this.

When _you_ are in a state of self-deception — and we've all been there — you do not tolerate contempt from others. It makes you see them as _bad people_ who need to be put in _their_ place. It helps justify your self-deception — and makes you respond in a way that helps them justify theirs. This isn't an accident.

Our parasites are _collaborating_ — and contempt is the secret tool they use to communicate, beneath our conscious thresholds. Our contempt telegraphs to others that our mind is in that dark space, subconsciously plotting to elevate or otherwise enrich ourselves at the world's expense — and it invites them to do the same, whether they are nominally friends or enemies.

We treat the "bad people" with contempt to help ourselves feel superior; to further distance ourselves and prove that we're nothing alike. Unfortunately, it is the surest sign that we _are._ We are shoving people deeper into the abyss and calling it "righteous." Rather than admit it, our minds hide this horrible truth by doubling down on our self-deception, so that we never suspect it.

We maintain a dividing line between the "fundamentally" good and bad; those who deserve our compassion and those who deserve our contempt. That boundary sometimes grows, as when we first discover that "hurt people hurt people." But the maintenance of _any division at all_ indicates that our "devil" still has its foot in the door. The line exists only to justify its continued presence.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/shared-devil.png"> 
</p>

If you look carefully enough, you will discover that our devils together behave more like a single malevolent distributed entity — the _Devil_, if you will. It is that archetypal "evil conspiracy" that we subconsciously fear exists — the one to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence, and to which they all ultimately report — _and every one of us is secretly in on it_. It remains hidden by keeping our attention fixated perpetually outward, blinding us to our own complicity.

Every time we feel malice, contempt, or self-righteousness; any time we are unkind to anyone for any reason, we are secretly feeding the Beast. Every act of unkindness ripples through its terrible body, lowering the threshold for more acts of evil to erupt in faraway locations — for which we will feel absolutely no complicity. But part of us always knows. This is what we must make conscious.

To be clear: there are surely groups of particularly "endarkened" people who consciously conspire to cause great harm, and **we must hold such people accountable**. But when it is motivated by contempt, we are reinforcing the very conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence — and a deep part of us knows this. It is as though the left hand does not know what the right is doing.

Nobody ultimately _wants_ to be under the sway of their devil — the key word being "ultimately." There are certainly people who willingly harbor it; those whom we classically think of as "evil." It would be foolish to be "kind" to them in the _conventional_ sense. Yet it is far _more_ foolish to feel malice, because that is **exactly** what their demon wants — and it is also where it is hardest to detect our own self-deception, and the easiest to justify it to others. It is the ultimate trap.

The more you unearth your own demon, the more clearly you see that such people are suffering from a kind of Stockholm syndrome — and the more obvious it becomes that  driving them toward their captor is malevolent. You are smothering what little light is left. It is literally the _worst_ time to be unkind. Unconventional means may be necessary to deal with them, but unkindness never is. If you believe that they _have_ no light, consider that this may be exactly the "trap" I described.

**True kindness is not about being _nice._** It can be fierce or even [violent](https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/dalai-gun/) if necessary. It is only about being lucidly aware of your own capacity to fall into self-deception, and refusing to do so. It is about staying connected to your Heart; that part of you that remembers the Truth — the very thing that your parasite is trying to make you forget. **Your fight is with the parasite. Hating the host just strengthens it.** Only your Light can bring about the better world you most deeply desire. The more you remember this, the more your very being helps others remember.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="600px" src="img/buddha-and-demons.png"> 
</p>

Your true nemesis is never other people, despite obvious appearances to the contrary. It is the darkness that has ensnared all of our minds. The more we come to recognize just how badly it has fooled _us_, the more we appreciate what the "bad people" are up against, and the more we can be of genuine service in dispelling it. We each have a role to play, and it always begins with us.

---

> *Like many of you (I'm sure), psilocybin has changed the way I see this world, and the people around me. It has torn my heart open on many occasions and revealed to me how my actions effect other people in ways I would've never imagined. In addition (and to the point), **psilocybin has increased my ability to empathize with people to a degree I never thought possible**.*
>
> *I consider this a blessing, but it has also led me to a very troubling conclusion:*
>
> *The lack of compassion, empathy and love we (society) feel for each other is staggering. Especially between people who don't know each other. The more love and empathy I feel for others, the more aware I am of society's inability to feel it for each other.*
>
> *Does this make sense? Does it mean this blessing is really a curse? Because sometimes, it feels that way.*

---

> *Nail on the head brother. My most recent mushroom trip (also the largest dose I've ever taken) I became fixated on a news story I had heard that week. About an 8 year old girl from a tribe in the Amazon, who was [tied to a tree and burned alive](https://www.survivalinternational.org/news/8033) in order to scare her people off their land so it could be logged. I realized that at the moment he did it, whoever lit that gasoline actually felt / thought more or less okay about what he was doing. **And my mind was illuminated with dozens of the parallels between that man's malformed, horrific perceptual / behavioral state, and mine. I saw the same mistakes in value attribution, the same willful ignorance of the consequences of my acts and words. And there was nothing I could do to deny the similarity.***
>
> *Reminds me of something (I think) Duncan [Trussell] said on some recent podcast, quoting somebody else: it isn't the victim of violence you have to pray for so much. It's the perpetrator. They are the one who is more trapped in delusion, more estranged from love, etc.*

(From a random web forum. Emphasis mine.)

> _For so long as the root of wickedness is hidden, it is strong. But when it is recognized, it is dissolved. When it is revealed, it perishes. ... It is powerful because we have not recognized it._ — The Gospel of Philip

Why is it so hard to maintain our humanity in the face of evil? And why are we "supposed to" in the first place?

You can subconsciously perceive that they are in the grip of a terrible demon that we ourselves share — indeed, that is controlling our mind _at this very moment_ — and the similarity horrifies you. The further you can push them into its grip, the more they will appear to be _fundamentally defective_, and thus unlike you.

This actually creates _new_ evil, but it doesn't feel like that. It feels like we are zeroing in on existing evil; exposing or distilling the hidden evil that is already there. It is as though we have finally caught a hold of the source of darkness in the world, and we can finally _punish_ it.

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light. So it is not strange that his ministers also masquerade as ministers of righteousness._ —2 Corinthians 11:14-16
 
This is a smokescreen created by your devil. It knows perfectly well that this will bring more darkness. In fact, that is its whole game. But it must never let you know this, and so it hides this behind _astonishingly_ seductive justifications that you don't even realize are seductions. All you consciously feel is "I'm fighting evil," and you have all the evidence to prove it.

Under the covers, their devil reached out to yours to offer it a secret handshake — and contempt was sign of your acceptance. No matter how well we try to mask this, people can subconsciously sense it. It invites everyone — ally and enemy alike — into that dark space of mind with us. What goes on in there isn't pretty.

There are surely groups of particularly "endarkened" people who consciously conspire to cause great harm, and **we must hold such people accountable**. So far I have been calling this all "subconscious," but that's not entirely accurate. > _For so long as the root of wickedness is hidden, it is strong. But when it is recognized, it is dissolved. When it is revealed, it perishes. ... It is powerful because we have not recognized it._ — The Gospel of Philip

Why is it so hard to maintain our humanity in the face of evil? And why are we "supposed to" in the first place?

---

All misbehavior — from cutting in line to genuine atrocities — is ultimately enabled by a kind of parasite in the mind. Think of it as that devil on our shoulders. But this devil doesn't just whisper obviously-evil ideas in our ears; no, it alters our very perception, so that it appears okay — or even _righteous_ — to step on certain people. It shields us from confronting the full implications of our words and behaviors.

The "bad people" know perfectly well when what they are doing is wrong, but that knowledge is very cleverly hidden from conscious self-reflection. If you try to viciously force them to confront it, it just drives the parasite deeper into their minds. But something in you already knows this.

When _you_ are in a state of self-deception — and we've all been there — you do not tolerate contemptuous judgement from others. Why? Because it signals to you that _they_ are in a state of self-deception and are in no position to be judging you. You see them as _bad people_ who need to be put in _their_ place, and feel _even more_ licensed to do whatever you need to do — which in turn convinces them that they were right about you all along. It is the contempt that drives this outcome, not the mere judgement (in the sense of _wise discernment_).

The same is true when the positions are reversed. Self-righteous outrage feels damn good — i.e., both enjoyable and virtuous — and yet something in you knows that it will just make them dig in their heels. In fact, that part of you _wants_ this, because it helps you prove just how _bad_ they are; how totally unlike you. But there's one small problem.

Subconsciously, you can perceive that they are actually in the grip of a terrible demon that you yourself share — indeed, one that is controlling your mind _at this very moment_ — and this similarity horrifies you. You shove them deeper into the abyss to hide this fact from yourself — because the deeper they go, the easier it gets to perceive them as _fundamentally_ defective, and not as a fellow human who badly needs help. (Indeed, beyond a certain point, even _they_ cannot consciously perceive this of themselves. At that point, who can really blame us?)

This actually creates _new_ evil, but it doesn't feel like that. It feels like you are zeroing in on existing evil; exposing or distilling the hidden evil that is already there. It is as though you are finally catching a hold of the source of darkness in the world, and are finally _punishing_ it.

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light. So it is not strange that his ministers also masquerade as ministers of righteousness._ —2 Corinthians 11:14-16
 
This is all a smokescreen created by your devil. It knows perfectly well that this behavior darkens the world. In fact, that is its whole game. But it must never let you know this, and so it hides this behind _astonishingly_ seductive justifications that you don't even realize are seductions. All you consciously feel is "I'm fighting evil" — and you have all the evidence to prove it.

What "actually" happened was that under the covers, their devil reached out to yours to offer it a secret handshake — and you signaled agreement by generating contempt. _Contempt is the secret tool by which our devils coordinate, beneath our conscious thresholds._ No matter how carefully you disguise it — even from yourself — it always leaks out into the world.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/shared-devil.png"> 
</p>

If you look carefully, you will discover that our devils together behave more like a single malevolent distributed entity — the _Devil_, if you will. It is that archetypal "evil conspiracy" that we subconsciously fear exists — the one to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence, and to which they all ultimately report — _and every one of us is secretly in on it_. It remains hidden by keeping our attention fixated perpetually outward, blinding us to our own participation.

Every time we feel malice, contempt, or self-righteousness; any time we are unkind to anyone for any reason, we are secretly feeding the Beast. Every act of unkindness ripples through its terrible body, lowering the threshold for more acts of evil to erupt in faraway locations — for which we will feel absolutely no complicity. But part of us always knows.

To be clear, we're certainly not all equally complicit. There are surely groups of particularly "endarkened" people who consciously conspire to cause great harm, and **we must hold such people accountable**. But when we do so with contempt, we are reinforcing the very conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence — and a deep part of us knows this.

So far I have been calling this all "subconscious," but that's not entirely accurate. The greatest shock is discovering that it was somehow _always_ accessible to consciousness, if we'd just bothered to look. This isn't a judgement of us. We _want_ to look, but something keeps stopping us. Our duty is to discover whatever that is, and heal it.

Nobody ultimately _wants_ to be under the sway of their devil — the key word being "ultimately." There are certainly people who willingly harbor it; those whom we classically think of as "evil." It would be foolish to be "kind" to them in the _conventional_ sense. Yet it is far _more_ foolish to feel malice, because that is **exactly** what their demon wants — and it is also where it is hardest to detect our own self-deception, and the easiest to justify it to others. It is the ultimate trap.

The more you unearth your own demon, the more clearly you see that such people are suffering from a kind of Stockholm syndrome — and the more acutely you feel the malevolence of driving them toward their captor. It smothers what little light is left. (If you believe that they _have_ no light, consider that this may be exactly the "trap" I just described.) It is literally the _worst_ time to be unkind. Unconventional means may be necessary to deal with them, but unkindness never is. This could only be true if "kindness" does not mean what we usually think.

**True kindness is not about being _nice._** It can be fierce or even [violent](https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/dalai-gun/) if necessary. It only requires being lucidly aware of your own capacity for self-deception, and refusing to fall into it. It is about staying connected to your Heart; that part of you that remembers the Truth — the very thing that your parasite is lulling you into forgetting. **Your fight is with the parasite. Hating the host just strengthens it.** 

The more you remember this, the more your very way of being inspires others to remember. Then, bit by bit you notice that even "evil" has no fundamental essence; that it is not a thing that can be "fought." It is not a _presence_, but an _absence._ An absence of what? Of the perception of our deep interconnectedness and fundamental equality. Hating people for not yet perceiving this makes no sense. Only your Light can bring about the better world you most deeply desire — and only you know what form your Light must take to make that happen.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="600px" src="img/buddha-and-demons.png"> 
</p>

Our true nemesis is never other people, despite obvious appearance to the contrary. It is the delusion that has ensnared all of our minds. The more we come to recognize just how badly it has fooled us, the more we appreciate what the "bad people" are really up against, and the more we can be of genuine service in dispelling it. We each have a role to play, and it always begins with us.

---

> *Like many of you (I'm sure), psilocybin has changed the way I see this world, and the people around me. It has torn my heart open on many occasions and revealed to me how my actions effect other people in ways I would've never imagined. In addition (and to the point), **psilocybin has increased my ability to empathize with people to a degree I never thought possible**.*
>
> *I consider this a blessing, but it has also led me to a very troubling conclusion:*
>
> *The lack of compassion, empathy and love we (society) feel for each other is staggering. Especially between people who don't know each other. The more love and empathy I feel for others, the more aware I am of society's inability to feel it for each other.*
>
> *Does this make sense? Does it mean this blessing is really a curse? Because sometimes, it feels that way.*

---

> *Nail on the head brother. My most recent mushroom trip (also the largest dose I've ever taken) I became fixated on a news story I had heard that week. About an 8 year old girl from a tribe in the Amazon, who was [tied to a tree and burned alive](https://www.survivalinternational.org/news/8033) in order to scare her people off their land so it could be logged. I realized that at the moment he did it, whoever lit that gasoline actually felt / thought more or less okay about what he was doing. **And my mind was illuminated with dozens of the parallels between that man's malformed, horrific perceptual / behavioral state, and mine. I saw the same mistakes in value attribution, the same willful ignorance of the consequences of my acts and words. And there was nothing I could do to deny the similarity.***
>
> *Reminds me of something (I think) Duncan [Trussell] said on some recent podcast, quoting somebody else: it isn't the victim of violence you have to pray for so much. It's the perpetrator. They are the one who is more trapped in delusion, more estranged from love, etc.*

(From a random web forum. Emphasis mine.)

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/tribe.png"> 
</p>


{% comment %}
This allows us to feel superior, in a way that can plausibly be defended as righteous. We are only _fighting evil,_ after all.

We maintain a dividing line between the "fundamentally" good and bad; those who deserve our compassion and those who deserve our contempt. That boundary changes throughout life, as we develop increasing empathy. But the maintenance of _any division at all_ indicates that our "devil" still has its foot in the door. The line exists only to justify its continued presence.

The short answer to "why show evildoers compassion?" is that the only alternative is to be evil.
{% endcomment %}

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

There is an aspect within each person's mind that genuinely wants what's best for the world. Sometimes, it is extremely well hidden — as with the "evil people." But it is always there, even when they themselves are not aware of it. To the degree that you can perceive it in others, you can help empower it. This is _kindness_, and it comes from the part of _you_ that only ever wants what's best for the world. It doesn't mean being _nice._ Sometimes the kindest behavior is the opposite of nice.

There is also an aspect within each of us that blocks us from seeing this aspect of others, and even ourselves. In fact, what is blocking you from perceiving it in "bad people" is precisely the same thing that enables their bad behavior in the first place. It is also what allows us to be casually cruel or cold to people we barely know (but may _think_ we know), telling ourselves that we're helping. It is an illusion that we must see through if we are to survive.

---

> _For so long as the root of wickedness is hidden, it is strong. But when it is recognized, it is dissolved. When it is revealed, it perishes. ... It is powerful because we have not recognized it._ — The Gospel of Philip

All misbehavior — from cutting in line to genuine atrocities — is ultimately enabled by a kind of parasite in the mind. Think of it as that devil on our shoulders. But this devil doesn't just whisper obviously-evil ideas in our ears; no, it alters our very perception, so that it appears okay — or even _righteous_ — to step on certain people. It shields us from confronting the full implications of our words and behaviors.

The "bad people" know perfectly well when what they are doing is wrong, but that knowledge is very cleverly hidden from conscious self-reflection. If you try to viciously force them to confront it, it just drives the parasite deeper into their minds. But something in you already knows this.

When _you_ are in the grip of self-deception — and we've all been there — you do not tolerate contemptuous judgement from others. Why? Because it signals to you that _they_ are in a state of self-deception and are in no position to be judging you. You see them as _bad people_ who need to be put in _their_ place, and feel _even more_ licensed to do whatever you need to do — which in turn convinces them that they were right about you all along. It is the **contempt** that drives this outcome, not the mere **judgement** (in the sense of _wise discernment_).

The same is true when the positions are reversed. Self-righteous outrage feels damn good — i.e., both enjoyable and virtuous — and yet something in you knows that it will just make them dig in their heels. The hard thing to admit is that part of you _wants_ this, because it helps you prove just how _bad_ they are; how totally unlike you. But there's one small problem.

Subconsciously, you can perceive that they are actually in the grip of a terrible demon that you yourself share — indeed, that is controlling your mind _right now_ — and this similarity horrifies you. COMMIT: 3f607e6dfb33fb17160fc7347aef8db0ad8bc32e
DATE: 2024-03-12 15:40:48 -0500
MESSAGE: Half-rewritten index
================================

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

---

> _For so long as the root of wickedness is hidden, it is strong. But when it is recognized, it is dissolved. When it is revealed, it perishes. ... It is powerful because we have not recognized it._ — The Gospel of Philip

We think that hating "bad people" is a sign of the good within us, but it's actually a sign of something much darker.

"Bad people" are only able to do what they do thanks to a kind of self-deception that makes harming other people feel okay. The deepest part of them knows perfectly well that what they are doing is wrong, but that knowledge is carefully shielded from conscious self-reflection. It is often so well-shielded that it is impossible for us to believe that it exists at all — but it does.

Exactly the same mechanism lives within our very own minds, though we rarely recognize it. It is what allows us to mock our political opponents with glee. We tell ourselves that they deserve it, and that it is making the world a better place — and we _believe_ this with all our hearts. Except it's not really with _all_ our hearts. The very deepest part of us always knows better, but we carefully shield this knowledge from conscious self-reflection.

It's easy to get lost in speculation about whether such behavior is actually a net harm or good, especially because we don't get to see all of its downstream effects. Even if we do see the second-, third-, etc. order effects — like a humiliated father venting his frustration on his children, who then grow up to become "bad people" themselves — we never make the connection back to our own behavior. And even if by some miracle we do, it is easy to avoid feeling any complicity. Sure, we may have provoked him, but it was _his_ responsibility to handle it with grace. Why didn't he just become a _better person_, like we so clearly intended?

Instead of getting lost in such speculation, there's something else you can do. If you inspect your mind carefully enough during such speculation, you'll discover that it exists primarily to hide something that your subconscious mind is secretly doing from your consciousness.

You see, part of us actually _wants_ "bad people" to become worse. Why? Because this enables us to feel like _better people_ by comparison. But this is extremely hard to admit to ourselves. So our mind finds _exceedingly_ clever ways to push them further into the dark in ways that we can label "righteous." When executed well — which is most of the time — you will never even suspect that you're doing this. The very idea will sound offensively absurd. And if anyone tries to point it out, powerful defense mechanisms will kick in, making it even harder to see — especially if they do it with even a trace of contempt (for reasons we shall soon see).

The truth is that any time you are unkind; any time you feel contempt, malice, or self-righteousness toward _anyone_ for _any reason_; it is your ego operating, attempting to elevate or otherwise enrich yourself at the world's expense. It is _precisely_ the same mechanism that allows the "bad people" to do what they do — and when you give in to yours, you are reinforcing their tendency to give in to theirs. **And this reinforcement isn't an unfortunate side effect of your otherwise-noble intentions; it is in fact the _whole point_.**

To put it more simply: we don't hate bad people to make the world a better place; we hate them to make ourselves feel (and look) good _while making it worse_. In fact, we don't even have to feel hatred. Simply seeing a person as irredeemable is already an unmistakable sign that this terrible process is underway in your subconscious.

I realize this is a hard thing to accept, and that you're unlikely to believe me unless you've seen it clearly yourself. But I swear it is the truth — and it is something that you can discover firsthand yourself.

Seeing the full extent of it is what the Buddhists call _enlightenment._ You discover a shocking sense in which _you are everyone and everything._ The very deepest aspect of your mind is pure compassion, as is that of everyone else. But they've forgotten this, just as you yourself had for innumerable lifetimes. The very last thing you could ever want to do is continue to push them _further_ from realizing it — which is the inevitable effect of perceiving them as fundamentally separate from yourself; of forsaking them.

This is not some bleeding heart idea. Kindness does not mean being nice, or sweet, or tolerant, or understanding. It simply means seeing the nature of reality clearly, so that your behavior inspires others to remember the astonishing truth instead of pushing them away from it. Such behavior may be fierce or even violent; it may look nothing like conventional "kindness" on the surface. But the very deepest part of you always knows the difference.

All of the darkness in the world is intimately connected — and part of it lives within your very own mind. By keeping your portion alive, you ensure that it continues to flourish "out there." That is why everything comes down to knowing ourselves deeply, and healing that secret part of us. Only by doing so can we become aware of our complicity in having reinforced the conditions we decry, and to develop the capacity to take them apart.



---

All misbehavior — from cutting in line to genuine atrocities — is ultimately enabled by a kind of parasite in the mind. Think of it as that devil on our shoulders. But this devil doesn't just whisper obviously-evil ideas in our ears; no, it alters our very perception, so that it appears okay — or even _righteous_ — to step on certain people. It shields us from confronting the full implications of our words and behaviors.

The "bad people" know perfectly well when what they are doing is wrong, but that knowledge is very cleverly hidden from conscious self-reflection. If you try to viciously force them to confront it, it just drives the parasite deeper into their minds. But something in you already knows this.

When _you_ are in the grip of self-deception — and we've all been there — you do not tolerate contemptuous judgement from others. Why? Because it signals to you that _they_ are in a state of self-deception and are in no position to be judging you. You see them as _bad people_ who need to be put in _their_ place, and feel _even more_ licensed to do whatever you need to do — which in turn convinces them that they were right about you all along. It is the **contempt** that drives this outcome, not the mere **judgement** (in the sense of _wise discernment_).

The same is true when the positions are reversed. Self-righteous outrage feels damn good — i.e., both enjoyable and virtuous — and yet something in you knows that it will just make them dig in their heels. The hard thing to admit is that part of you _wants_ this, because it helps you prove just how _bad_ they are; how totally unlike you. But there's one small problem.

Subconsciously, you can perceive that they are actually in the grip of a terrible demon that you yourself share — indeed, that is controlling your mind _right now_ — and this similarity horrifies you. So you shove them deeper into the abyss to hide this fact from yourself — because the deeper they go, the easier it is to perceive them as _fundamentally defective_, as opposed to fellow humans who badly need help. (Indeed, beyond a certain point, even _they_ cannot consciously perceive this of themselves. At that point, who can really blame us for being cruel?)

This actually creates _new_ evil, but it doesn't feel like that. It feels like you are zeroing in on existing evil; exposing or distilling the hidden evil that is already there. It is as though you are finally catching a hold of the source of darkness in the world, and are finally _punishing_ it. It feels impossibly righteous to be nasty to "bad people."

> _And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as an angel of light. So it is not strange that his ministers also masquerade as ministers of righteousness._ —2 Corinthians 11:14-16
 
But this is all a smokescreen created by your devil. It knows perfectly well that this behavior darkens the world. In fact, that is its whole game. But it must never let you know this, and so it hides this behind _astonishingly_ seductive justifications that you don't even realize are seductions. All you consciously feel is "I'm fighting evil" — and you have all the evidence to prove it.

What "actually" happened was that under the covers, _their_ devil reached out to yours to offer it a secret handshake — and you signaled agreement simply by feeling contempt. **Contempt is the secret tool by which our devils coordinate, beneath our conscious thresholds.** It is the opposite of kindness; that part of you that wants what's best for everyone. No matter how carefully you disguise it — even from yourself — it always leaks out into the world.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/shared-devil.png"> 
</p>

If you look carefully, you will discover that our devils together behave more like a single malevolent distributed entity — the _Devil_, if you will. It is that archetypal "evil conspiracy" that we subconsciously fear exists — the one to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence, and to which they all ultimately report — _and every one of us is secretly in on it_. It remains hidden by keeping our attention fixated perpetually outward, blinding us to our own participation.

Every time we feel malice, contempt, or self-righteousness; any time we are unkind to anyone for any reason, we are secretly feeding the Beast. Every act of unkindness ripples through its terrible body, lowering the threshold for more acts of evil to erupt in faraway locations — for which we will feel absolutely no complicity. But part of us always knows.

To be clear, we're certainly not all equally complicit. There are surely groups of particularly "endarkened" people who consciously conspire to cause great harm, and **we must hold such people accountable**. But when we do so with contempt, we are reinforcing the very conditions that effectively _compel_ their existence — and a deep part of us knows this.

So far I have been calling this all "subconscious," but that's not entirely accurate. The greatest shock is discovering that it was somehow _always_ accessible to consciousness, if we'd just bothered to look. This isn't a judgement of us. We _want_ to look, but something keeps stopping us. Our duty is to discover whatever that is, and heal it.

Nobody ultimately _wants_ to be under the sway of their devil — the key word being "ultimately." There are certainly people who willingly harbor it; those whom we classically think of as "evil." It would be foolish to be "kind" to them in the _conventional_ sense. Yet it is far _more_ foolish to feel malice, because that is **exactly** what their demon wants — and it is also where it is hardest to detect our own self-deception, and the easiest to justify it to others. It is the ultimate trap.

The more you unearth your own demon, the more clearly you see that such people are suffering from a kind of Stockholm syndrome — and the more acutely you feel the malevolence of driving them toward their captor. It smothers what little light is left. (If you believe that they _have_ no light, consider that this may be exactly the "trap" I just described.) It is literally the _worst_ time to be unkind. Unconventional means may be necessary to deal with them, but unkindness never is. This could only be true if "kindness" does not mean what we usually think.

**True kindness is not about being _nice._** It can be fierce or even [violent](https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/dalai-gun/) if necessary. It only requires being lucidly aware of your own capacity for self-deception, and refusing to fall into it. It is about staying connected to your Heart; that part of you that remembers the Truth — the very thing that your parasite is lulling you into forgetting. **Your fight is with the parasite. Hating the host just strengthens it.** 

The more you remember this, the more your very way of being inspires others to remember. Then, bit by bit you notice that even "evil" has no fundamental essence; that it is not a thing that can be "fought." It is not a _presence_, but an _absence._ An absence of what? Of the perception of our deep interconnectedness and fundamental equality. Hating people for not yet perceiving this makes no sense. Only your Light can bring about the better world you most deeply desire — and only you know what form your Light must take to make that happen.

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="600px" src="img/buddha-and-demons.png"> 
</p>

Our true nemesis is never other people, despite obvious appearance to the contrary. It is the delusion that has ensnared all of our minds. The more we come to recognize just how badly it has fooled us, the more we appreciate what the "bad people" are really up against, and the more we can be of genuine service in dispelling it. We each have a role to play, and it always begins with us.

---

> *Like many of you (I'm sure), psilocybin has changed the way I see this world, and the people around me. It has torn my heart open on many occasions and revealed to me how my actions effect other people in ways I would've never imagined. In addition (and to the point), **psilocybin has increased my ability to empathize with people to a degree I never thought possible**.*
>
> *I consider this a blessing, but it has also led me to a very troubling conclusion:*
>
> *The lack of compassion, empathy and love we (society) feel for each other is staggering. Especially between people who don't know each other. The more love and empathy I feel for others, the more aware I am of society's inability to feel it for each other.*
>
> *Does this make sense? Does it mean this blessing is really a curse? Because sometimes, it feels that way.*

---

> *Nail on the head brother. My most recent mushroom trip (also the largest dose I've ever taken) I became fixated on a news story I had heard that week. About an 8 year old girl from a tribe in the Amazon, who was [tied to a tree and burned alive](https://www.survivalinternational.org/news/8033) in order to scare her people off their land so it could be logged. I realized that at the moment he did it, whoever lit that gasoline actually felt / thought more or less okay about what he was doing. **And my mind was illuminated with dozens of the parallels between that man's malformed, horrific perceptual / behavioral state, and mine. I saw the same mistakes in value attribution, the same willful ignorance of the consequences of my acts and words. And there was nothing I could do to deny the similarity.***
>
> *Reminds me of something (I think) Duncan [Trussell] said on some recent podcast, quoting somebody else: it isn't the victim of violence you have to pray for so much. It's the perpetrator. They are the one who is more trapped in delusion, more estranged from love, etc.*

(From a random web forum. Emphasis mine.)

<p align="center" width="100%">
    <img width="300px" src="img/tribe.png"> 
</p>


{% comment %}
This allows us to feel superior, in a way that can plausibly be defended as righteous. We are only _fighting evil,_ after all.

We maintain a dividing line between the "fundamentally" good and bad; those who deserve our compassion and those who deserve our contempt. That boundary changes throughout life, as we develop increasing empathy. But the maintenance of _any division at all_ indicates that our "devil" still has its foot in the door. The line exists only to justify its continued presence.

The short answer to "why show evildoers compassion?" is that the only alternative is to be evil.

COMMIT: 9f418b6b1d90c4b60b6643a7248cb24f5050f8bf
DATE: 2024-04-09 09:26:40 -0500
MESSAGE: Best index yet
================================

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

---

> _For so long as the root of wickedness is hidden, it is strong. But when it is recognized, it is dissolved. When it is revealed, it perishes. ... It is powerful because we have not recognized it._ — The Gospel of Philip

What if nearly everything you're doing to "fight evil" is secretly strengthening it — and moreover, what if part of you already knows this, but is actively concealing it from your conscious mind?

---

Take a moment to reflect on what's wrong with the world, and bring to mind the people responsible. Don't they seem not only morally defective, but somehow _fundamentally_ so? Such people cannot be helped; they can only be subdued or punished. Treating them with contempt is therefore not only acceptable but positively _righteous_.

This is an illusion. People are only able to misbehave due to a kind of self-deception: part of them knows perfectly well that they are doing wrong, but that knowledge is very cleverly shielded from conscious self-reflection. The more powerful this shielding, the more "evil" the person appears. In fact, this is the very mechanism that has enabled _all the evil there ever was_ — and it is what has enabled our own misbehavior too, if we're honest. We have all skirted our conscience before, pretending either that we couldn't hear it or that we didn't have to. Ours may differ in degree, but not in kind.

We don't mock and shame our political enemies to help them (or anyone else) "see the light," or to make the world a better place. We do it to feel superior while _telling_ ourselves that we're helping. We don't get to see all the downstream effects — a humiliated (and perhaps already-overworked) father taking his embarrassment out on his children, who then grow up to become "bad people" themselves. And even if by some miracle we do, we avoid acknowledging our own complicity. Sure, we may have provoked him, but he could have used it as an opportunity to become _better_. The fact that he didn't just proves that he's _bad_. Of course, there may also be some positive effects, such as temporarily suppressing his misbehavior (in public, anyway). But while it's impossible to prove whether the net result is good or bad, there is something that we _can_ know.

If you look carefully enough into your mind while feeling contempt — and this is _hard_ — you'll discover that it is secretly designed to darken the world. We _want_ our enemies to dig in their heels, because it vindicates our perception of them. If we can confirm that they are as bad as we feared, then we will eventually be justified in unleashing the full extent of our righteous fury — and there is nothing more primally satisfying than violently destroying evil. So we behave in ways that very cleverly trigger their defense mechanisms; to *strengthen* their capacity for self-deception. It is as though we are trying to draw out the evil that we _know_ is there, but in actuality we are creating more. You have **no idea** how good you are at creating and maintaining enemies to support your worldview. That's because the part of you that does this hides itself from your consciousness just as cleverly as "bad people's" misbehavior is hidden from them. It is completely accessible to consciousness, if you look. But somehow, we never look.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/half-evil.png"></p>

This is **profound** self-deception. As such, you are unlikely to believe me when I tell you that this is what is really happening, unless you've already seen it clearly operating in yourself. Our seemingly-innocent perception of people as _fundamentally defective_ is a very clever ploy. It doesn't stay restricted to our minds. We use all of our capacities to _enforce_ it onto reality. Whatever little potential people may have to become free of their darkness, we violently squeeze out of them with our firm conviction that they have no such potential. We don't even have to be in direct contact with them to have this effect: one way or another, our darkness _always_ finds a way to leak into the world, slowly massaging it into the shape we need for everything to make sense to us. And this isn't just a wild hypothesis: you can learn to see it for yourself.

It is a profoundly humbling realization when you first discover it. How did we ever expect the "bad people" to confront their self-deception when we — the "good people" — couldn't detect our own? We are left with no leg to stand on. It is only once you see this clearly that you begin to appreciate the magnitude of what the "bad people" are up against — and that you learn to be of genuine service in fighting it.

> _Why do you look at the speck of sawdust in your brother’s eye and pay no attention to the plank in your own eye? How can you say to your brother, ‘Let me take the speck out of your eye,’ when all the time there is a plank in your own eye? You hypocrite, first take the plank out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the speck from your brother’s eye._ —Matthew 7:3-5

---

Self-deception is caused by a kind of parasite in the mind whose job is to make us feel different and special. It alters our very perception of reality, making us behave in ways that bolster our self-image.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/parasite.png"></p>

For some people this may be about accumulating wealth or having the "right" skin color, while in others it is simply about being a "good person." That last one may seem noble, but it creates a perverse incentive: the only way to be "good" in the relative sense is for "bad" people to exist. The worse other people become, the better we look by comparison. Thus, our subconscious is on the prowl for people it can make worse. But of course, being "good people," we can't do this to just anyone. So our parasite makes certain people appear _fundamentally defective_, so that harming them suddenly becomes noble. Everyone else must be treated with "compassion," and we make a big show of being their saviors.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/good-vs-bad.png"></p>

This works, for a while. The problem is that the more we do this, the more we begin to suspect a disturbing truth: such behavior isn't evidence of how _different_ we are from the "bad people," but how _similar_ we are. We have two options at this point: to admit and renounce the sordid  game we've been playing, or to double down. For the most part, we choose the latter. We drive this knowledge ever-further out of consciousness, securely locking it away under lock and key. But we cannot outrun it forever.

Sooner or later, the funhouse of mirrors comes crashing down, and we are forced to confront what profound hypocrites we've been. This discovery hurts like Hell — but it also triggers the deepest introspection of our lives. We discover that we never wanted to do this. We never wanted to hurt anyone, and ultimately never _could_ want such a thing — because what we are in our innermost selves is _pure, unadulterated Goodness._ This is a very difficult thing to describe without sounding "woo," but there's no other way to put it without losing its enormity.

The deepest aspect of your mind is pure compassion; Light beyond measure. Its only job is to dispel the darkness in the world. As astonishing as this realization is, what's even more remarkable is that when you see it in yourself, you simultaneously see it in everybody else, too. That's because, in a profound and surprising sense, [you _are_ everybody and everything else](unity.md). In a flash, you discover the full extent of the horrifying confusion that binds humanity. You somehow perceive all the great battles that have led to the creation of "evil people." By forsaking them, you are only forsaking Yourself. Such behavior is itself "evil," but you only did it because you weren't ready to come Home yet. Everyone else was similarly lost, and in their deep confusion tried to prevent you from coming Home too. That's all "evil" ultimately _is_ — an innocent mistake that has grown to truly epic proportions.

I know this story may be hard to swallow, but I promise that it's something you can discover for yourself. Indeed, the deepest part of you already knows it.

By discovering your _absolute_ goodness, you begin to relinquish your need for _relative_ goodness. This undoes the illusion that motivates contempt. You slowly lose the dark urge to push people further into the abyss. Instead, you start to discover a better way. But before we explore that way, let's look at this whole thing from another angle.

---

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/devil-vs-devil.png"></p>

When you treat a "bad person" with contempt, you are secretly indicating to their parasite that you are similarly infected. It is a kind of secret handshake — one that their parasite readily accepts. Both you and your enemy will behave in ways that provide the _other_ person's parasite with exactly the excuses it needs to embed itself deeper into its host. In this way, _all_ of our parasites are intimately connected. In fact, they aren't truly separate. If you look closely enough, you'll discover that they behave more like a single distributed malevolent entity, communicating with itself beneath our conscious thresholds. If our parasites are that little devil on our shoulders, then this "entity" is the _Devil._

It continually drives humanity toward various kinds of Armageddon: situations in which everyone is violently proving how _righteous_ they are. It is why the US is headed toward civil war without anyone suspecting their own complicity, and explains bitter [divorces](https://www.gottman.com/blog/this-one-thing-is-the-biggest-predictor-of-divorce/) in which each side feels like the exclusive victim / hero. Nearly the whole world is caught in its terrible sway, evil provoking "righteous" retribution at every turn, without anyone ever noticing the true source of it all.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/shared-devil.png"></p>

You know that "evil global conspiracy" that some people fear exists — the one that's somehow responsible for all the world's ills, yet which hides itself so perfectly that people never even suspect its existence? Well, _this is it_ — the _primordial_ evil conspiracy; the one to which all the rest ultimately owe their existence, and to which they all filter up. The reason we can't pin it down "out there" is because it lives deep within the shadows of all of our own minds. From in there, it knows _exactly_ what buttons to press to prevent us from ever suspecting our own involvement.

It may well be true that "the elites" are playing regular people off each other to take attention away from them, but the Devil is playing a _much_ larger game; one in which the elites are merely pawns. It's not that they mustn't be stopped — it's that the contempt with which we do so reinforces the very conditions that effectively compel their existence in the first place. The details of who is in power may change, but their underlying essence does not — and _cannot_ for as long as we're unaware of our own complicity. Every single act of unkindness that we perpetrate ripples out into the world, influencing faraway events, so that we never notice our connection to them.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/evil-conspiracy.png"></p>

To be clear: there are certainly people who are knowingly and intentionally causing mayhem, and for whom the label "evil" may indeed serve a useful purpose. But if you still perceive this evil as _intrinsic_ to their minds, it only means that your own parasite is still operating, cleverly tempting you. People who are free of their parasites simply do not perceive reality this way. They cannot feel even the slightest trace of malice, contempt, or self-righteousness toward _anyone_. That's because they are able to perceive the part of people that genuinely wants to be _free_ of their parasite. This enables them to act with compassion — the "better way" that we hinted at before.

---

Compassion (aka kindness) does not mean being nice, or sweet, or forgiving, or even understanding. It is simply the absence of self-deception. It can be as fierce (or potentially even violent) as the situation warrants. But it never falls into the illusion of being fundamentally better than anyone, and this makes all the difference.

Again, when you show contempt — for the _person_, not just their ideas or behavior — you are putting your own self-deception on clear display. The deepest part of you knows that you're not ultimately better than anyone (like you are currently pretending to be). And the deepest part of _them_ can see this, even if only subconsciously. They can sense that you are a hypocrite, and this enables them to ignore any genuinely righteous content in your message. Even worse, it teaches them that there _are_ no genuinely decent people; that even the "good people" are just faking it. Any "inner Light" thus becomes even more of a naive myth.

When self-deception is absent, the opposite occurs. Their parasite is confronted with the one thing it cannot stand: authentic Goodness. It is robbed of its power to justify its own existence, because it is in the presence of something immeasurably greater and truer. This is _very_ difficult to describe, but I know you've felt it before. Everything comes down to standing firmly in your inner Light, _especially_ when confronted with the greatest depths of Darkness, when you are most tempted to abandon it. It may not eliminate evil as quickly as you'd like, or be as deliciously satisfying as giving in to self-righteousness, but it is the _only_ way toward the world your heart most deeply desires.

Ultimately, the Darkness is not an entity in its own right, but merely the absence of Light. The fact that it can _behave_ like such an entity — the Devil — is truly one of the most astonishing facts of existence. This is why, as MLK Jr said:

> *Darkness cannot drive out darkness, only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate, only love can do that.* ― Martin Luther King, Jr.

His words stand true as ever.

---

Your real enemy is not actually other people, but the remarkable self-deception that has overtaken our minds. Its horsemen are malice, contempt, and self-righteousness. May we uproot these dark tendencies in ourselves so that we may join the fight against it — the only fight that ultimately matters.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="600px" src="img/buddha-and-demons.png"></p>

> _Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle._ —Author unknown

---

> _For so long as the root of wickedness is hidden, it is strong. But when it is recognized, it is dissolved. When it is revealed, it perishes. ... It is powerful because we have not recognized it._ — The Gospel of Philip

What if nearly everything you're doing to "fight evil" is secretly strengthening it — and moreover, what if part of you already knows this, but is actively concealing it from your conscious mind?

---

Take a moment to reflect on what's wrong with the world, and bring to mind the people responsible — the greedy bankers; the hypocritical CEOs; the corrupt politicians (and all who support them). Don't they seem not only morally defective, but somehow _fundamentally_ so? Such people cannot be helped; they can only be subdued or punished. Treating them with contempt is therefore not only acceptable but positively righteous.

This is an illusion. People are only able to misbehave due to a kind of self-deception: part of them knows perfectly well that they are doing wrong, but that knowledge is very cleverly shielded from conscious self-reflection. The more powerful this shielding, the more "evil" the person appears. In fact, it is this very mechanism that has enabled _all the evil there ever was_ — and it has enabled our own misbehavior too, if we're honest. We have all skirted our conscience before, pretending either that we couldn't hear it or that we didn't have to. Our own instances may differ in degree, but not in kind.

When we encounter others in this state, we feel compelled to rub their noses in it. By forcing them to confront just how _bad_ they are, we expect that they will stop — and when they don't, we feel that we have no choice but to escalate. What we can't see is that this itself is profound self-deception — and self-deception is a group phenomenon. By trying to convince people that they are _fundamentally defective_, we are triggering their defense mechanisms — and we _know_ what the result will be.

We don't mock and shame our political enemies to help them (or anyone else) "see the light," or to make the world a better place. We do it to feel superior while _telling_ ourselves that we're helping. We don't get to see all the downstream effects — a humiliated (and perhaps overworked) father taking his embarrassment out on his children, who then grow up to become "bad people" themselves. And even if by some miracle we do, we avoid acknowledging our own complicity. Sure, we may have provoked him, but why didn't he use it as an opportunity to become _better_? This just proves that he's _bad_. Of course, there may also be some positive effects, such as temporarily suppressing his misbehavior (in public, anyway). But while it's hard to know whether the net result is good or bad (think _butterfly effect_), there is something that we _can_ know.

If you look carefully enough into your mind while feeling contempt — and this is hard — you'll discover that it is secretly _designed_ to darken the world. We _want_ our enemies to dig in their heels, because it vindicates our perception of them. If we can confirm that they are as bad as we feared, then we will eventually be justified in unleashing the full extent of our righteous fury — and there is nothing more primally satisfying than violently destroying evil. So we behave in ways that very cleverly trigger their defense mechanisms; to *strengthen* their capacity for self-deception. It is as though we are trying to draw out the evil that we "know" is already in there, but in actuality we are creating more.

You have **no idea** how good you are at creating and maintaining enemies to justify and reinforce your view of the world; your infallible inner story of "good guys" and "bad guys." That's because the part of you that does this hides itself from your consciousness just as cleverly as "bad people's" misbehavior is hidden from them. It is completely accessible to consciousness, if you look. But somehow, we never look. Something within us knows that if we were forced to confront our own self-deception, our whole perception of the world — and the stories of blame that scaffold it — would suddenly come crashing down.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/half-evil.png"></p>

It is **profound** self-deception. As such, you are unlikely to believe me when I tell you that this is what is really happening, unless you've already seen it clearly operating in yourself. Our seemingly-innocent perception of people as _fundamentally defective_ is not so innocent. It does not stay confined to our own minds: we use all of our capacities to _enforce_ it onto reality. Whatever little potential that people may have to become free of their darkness, we violently squeeze out of them with our firm conviction that they have no such potential. One way or another, our darkness _always_ finds a way to leak into the world, slowly massaging it into the shape we need for everything to make sense to us. Even if we're not in direct contact with our target, we ensure that our contempt darkens the minds of those in our orbit — our "allies" and bystanders. And this isn't just a wild hypothesis: you can learn to see it for yourself.

It is a profoundly humbling realization when you first discover it. How did we ever expect the "bad people" to confront their self-deception when we — the "good people" — couldn't detect our own? We are left with no leg to stand on. It is only once you see this clearly that you begin to appreciate the magnitude of what the "bad people" are up against — and that you learn to be of genuine service in fighting it.

> _Why do you look at the speck of sawdust in your brother’s eye and pay no attention to the plank in your own eye? How can you say to your brother, ‘Let me take the speck out of your eye,’ when all the time there is a plank in your own eye? You hypocrite, first take the plank out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the speck from your brother’s eye._ —Matthew 7:3-5

---

Self-deception is caused by a kind of parasite in the mind. Think of it as that little devil on your shoulder. But unlike in the cartoons, this devil doesn't just whisper obviously-bad ideas in your ear; no, it alters your very perception at such a fundamental level that you don't even realize you're being seduced. You just see it as "reality."

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/parasite.png"></p>

The key point is that it is a _parasite._ Unlike your angel — which is intrinsic to your mind, and represents your fundamental goodness — your devil can be evicted, bit by bit. But every time you listen to it — that is, every time you give in to your self-deception — it burrows a little bit deeper into your mind, feeling more and more like "you" with each step. The more this happens, the more you appear "evil" to others.

People don't listen to it because they're _bad_ — even though it (very convincingly) appears that way. Instead, the confluence of experiences they've had — which you can think of as having accumulated over lifetimes, or perhaps in what we now think of as their epigenome — somehow makes them feel like listening to it is the "right" thing to do. They have been very cleverly lulled to sleep.

The point is not to feel sorry for evil people, but to gain insight into the bizarre mechanism that has overtaken their minds. The most important thing to see here is that the very same mechanism exists in yours. It is _your_ parasite that makes you see them (or anyone else) as _fundamentally defective_; to see their evil as somehow intrinsic to their minds.

It is well known that even Hitler thought that he was doing something noble. I'll refrain from quoting him directly[^Hitler], but he genuinely believed that he was saving the world from the Devil, which had somehow manifested into the world as the Jewish people. It is easy for us to recognize this as profound delusion, but it is much harder to see that the vile misperception that affected him is _precisely_ the same one that makes us perceive him as "intrinsically" evil; something that we ourselves could never ever be.

This is a subtle point, so I don't want it to be misunderstood. He was surely deluded enough to deserve the label "evil," and being kind to him in the conventional sense would have been dangerously stupid. But the belief that he (and the Nazi army) were somehow _fundamentally_ different from us is a dark lie that our parasite uses to invite itself deeper into our minds, bit by bit. Its whole trick is to make you believe that you are special and immune; that only _other_ people are susceptible. This is how you learn to overlook your own misbehavior, quickly becoming convinced that you either don't have any, or that yours isn't causing much harm to the world.

---

Our parasite leverages our primal need to see ourselves as "good people" to cause mayhem. This instinct may seem noble, but it creates a perverse incentive: the only way to be "good" in the relative sense is for "bad" people to exist. The worse other people become, the better we look by comparison. Thus, our subconscious is on the prowl for people it can _make_ worse. But of course, being "good people," we can't do this to just anyone. So our parasite makes us see some people as _fundamentally defective_, so that harming them suddenly becomes noble. Everyone else must be treated with "compassion," and we make a big show of being their saviors.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/good-vs-bad.png"></p>

This works — for a while. The problem is that the more we do this, the more we begin to suspect a disturbing truth: such behavior isn't evidence of how _different_ we are from the "bad people," but how _similar_ we are. We have two options at this point: to admit and renounce the sordid  game we've been playing, or to double down. For the most part, we choose the latter. We drive this knowledge ever-further out of consciousness, securely locking it away under lock and key. But we cannot outrun it forever.

Sooner or later, the funhouse of mirrors comes crashing down, and we are forced to confront what profound hypocrites we've been. This discovery hurts like Hell — but it also triggers the deepest introspection of our lives. We discover that we never wanted to do this. We never wanted to hurt anyone, and ultimately never _could_ want such a thing — because what we are in our innermost selves is _pure, unadulterated Goodness._ This is a very difficult thing to describe without sounding "woo," but there's no other way to put it without losing its enormity.

The deepest aspect of your mind is pure compassion; Light beyond measure. Its only job is to dispel the darkness in the world. As astonishing as this realization is, what's even more remarkable is that when you see it in yourself, you simultaneously see it in everybody else, too. That's because, in a profound and surprising sense, [you _are_ everybody and everything else](unity.md). In a flash, you discover the full extent of the horrifying confusion that binds humanity. You somehow perceive all the great battles that have led to the creation of "evil people." By forsaking them, you are only forsaking Yourself. Such behavior is itself "evil," but you only did it because you weren't ready to come Home yet. Everyone else was similarly lost, and in their deep confusion tried to prevent you from coming Home too. That's all "evil" ultimately _is_ — an innocent mistake that has grown to truly epic proportions.

I know this story may be hard to swallow, but I promise that it's something you can discover for yourself. Indeed, the deepest part of you already knows it.

By discovering your _absolute_ goodness, you begin to relinquish your need for _relative_ goodness. This undoes the illusion that motivates contempt. You slowly lose the dark urge to push people further into the abyss. Instead, you start to discover a better way. But before we explore that way, let's look at this whole thing from another angle.

---

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/devil-vs-devil.png"></p>

When you treat a "bad person" with contempt, you are secretly indicating to their parasite that you are similarly infected. It is a kind of secret handshake — one that their parasite readily accepts. Both you and your enemy will behave in ways that provide the _other_ person's parasite with exactly the excuses it needs to embed itself deeper into its host. In this way, _all_ of our parasites are intimately connected. In fact, they aren't truly separate. If you look closely enough, you'll discover that they behave more like a single distributed malevolent entity, communicating with itself beneath our conscious thresholds. If our parasites are that little devil on our shoulders, then this "entity" is the _Devil._

It continually drives humanity toward various kinds of Armageddon: situations in which everyone is violently proving how _righteous_ they are. It is why the US is headed toward civil war without anyone suspecting their own complicity, and explains bitter [divorces](https://www.gottman.com/blog/this-one-thing-is-the-biggest-predictor-of-divorce/) in which each side feels like the exclusive victim / hero. Nearly the whole world is caught in its terrible sway, evil provoking "righteous" retribution at every turn, without anyone ever noticing the true source of it all.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/shared-devil.png"></p>

You know that "evil global conspiracy" that some people fear exists — the one that's somehow responsible for all the world's ills, yet which hides itself so perfectly that people never even suspect its existence? From in there, it knows _exactly_ what buttons to press to prevent us from ever suspecting our own involvement.

COMMIT: e40549bf88dab5cbf3dea4ed6ba7b4f3c5cb2f8c
DATE: 2024-04-26 09:19:03 -0500
MESSAGE: Once more...
================================

Why are we unkind to people who we perceive as "bad"? The answer seems obvious: we do it to make the world a better place. But this is an insidious lie. It explains why we're not _nice_, but not why we're not _kind_. Nice is about being pleasant and agreeable, which are clearly unhelpful in some situations. But kindness means something much deeper. It is the right motivation in _every_ circumstance.

---

A healthy mind harbors no hostility under any circumstances. That's not because it is meek or even "tolerant" per se. It can be fierce or even violent in subduing evil. These can be forms of kindness too. But it cannot feel even a _trace_ of malice, contempt, or self-righteousness, because it has seen something clearly.

It has seen that those sentiments are lies: they exist *only* to help us get away with something that we otherwise could not. We want to behave in some way that is self-serving, which we couldn't do if we could see the full humanity of the person we are attacking. So a dark aspect of our mind tricks us into perceiving them as somehow _fundamentally defective_. That way, we won't feel bad harming them. It might not even be obvious what we're getting out of it. For some, it is financial gain or feelings of power, but very often it is (ironically) just to bolster our self-image as "good people," who therefore deserve to get away with more. A deep part of us recognizes this deceit, but we carefully hide it away from conscious self-reflection.

We feel like we are teaching the other person a lesson, but they may not even be (knowingly) doing anything wrong. They may be honestly doing the best they can, in which case we're harming an innocent person. But even if they _are_ knowingly doing wrong, it's only because they're under the sway of _precisely_ the same self-deception that we presently are. Either way, the only "lesson" they learn is that this world is a dark and phony place; that the Light is just a myth. Whatever temporary benefit we may achieve — such as suppressing their (public) misbehavior — this powerfully reinforces their self-deception. This in turn proves to _us_ that the world is a nasty place, thus requiring our "righteous" escalation.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/half-evil.png"></p>

You have _no idea_ how good your subconscious is at telegraphing your darkness to others while simultaneously hiding it from yourself. This combination sets up perfect feedback loop, in which you can trigger the darkness in others while convincing yourself that it's their fault. And this is far from the only way that your darkness leaks out. As long as you are harboring any hardness or hostility in your heart, it _will_ find its way into the world, one way or another, without your conscious knowledge. Except it's not truly unconscious: it is always available to consciousness, if we choose to look. The problem is that we _choose not to look_.

Here is the choice that confronts each one of us: to become aware of having chosen to look away — and thereby discover that this is how _all_ evil works, and that our self-righteous judgement therefore has no basis whatsoever — or to continue to delude ourselves, descending into deeper and deeper realms of self-deception, darkening the world in increasingly clever ways, ever-more convinced of our righteousness.

---

Evil is actually an absence masquerading as a presence. The absence of what? Of a particular insight.

The ultimate truth is that you are everyone and everything, in a profound and surprising sense. It is said that this is only fully realized upon _enlightenment,_ but all of us can sense it at all times, to some degree or another. Yet we hide it from ourselves. It is only by overlooking this astonishing truth that anyone is able to harm anyone else (or our planet), through objectification; dehumanization. This is the core of self-deception; the origin of all contempt; the root of all evil.

But although it is an absence, it behaves very convincingly like a presence. When you look in the eyes of someone in the grip of this delusion, you see the _presence_ of evil. This is the moment of truth. If you choose profound honesty, you will be forced to admit that the same potential exists within you, and you will gain at least some insight in how to alleviate theirs, commensurate with your willingness; your deep compassion. This will contribute to the healing of the world. Compassion is never truly "for" a person, but for everything at once.

Your darkness, on the other hand, seduces you into believing that you could never be like them; that you are _fundamentally superior_. If you accede, you will perceive them as _intrinsically defective_, thus inspiring contempt. Their darkness will instantly recognize itself in you, and the game is on. Now both yours and theirs are secretly _allied_, knowing that they can freely spread darkness in the world with the implicit permission of you, their hosts. You have both willingly gone unconscious; delegated your sovereignty.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/parasite.png"></p>

It is that devil on your shoulder. It is a kind of mental parasite, fundamentally extrinsic to your mind. But unlike in the cartoons, it doesn't just whisper obviously-bad ideas into your ear. No, it alters your very perception so that other people's devils appear intrinsic. This way, you will feel justified in shoving them deeper into the abyss in the name of "good." Everyone else is treated sweetly and gingerly, as if to prove to ourselves and the world which team we are fighting for.

<p align="center" width="100%"><img width="300px" src="img/good-vs-bad.png"></p>

But our devils are more than just allied. With enough sensitivity, you will see that they behave more like outgrowths of a single distributed malevolent entity — the _Devil,_ if you will. It hides itself in our subconscious, flowing freely between minds, with none of us ever detecting its presence, convinced that we are uniquely immune to its sinister charms. It continually drives humanity toward various kinds of Armageddon: situations in which everyone is violently proving how _righteous_ they are. It is why the US is headed toward civil war without anyone suspecting their own complicity, and explains bitter [divorces](https://www.gottman.com/blog/this-one-thing-is-the-biggest-predictor-of-divorce/) in which each side feels like the exclusive victim / hero. Nearly the whole world is caught in its terrible sway, evil provoking "righteous" retribution at every turn, without anyone ever noticing the true source of it all.

It is said that the elites are playing us off each other to take attention off of them, but the Devil is playing a _much_ bigger game — one in which even the elites are merely pawns. It tricks you into hating them specifically so that you will empower it — and thereby empower _them_. It is the reason that nothing ever seems to change. It accomplishes this by convincing you that your compassion isn't powerful enough to combat their evil; that your darkness is required.

It is that "evil global conspiracy" that some people fear exists: a covert entity responsible for all the world's ills, that hides itself so perfectly that nobody ever suspects its existence, let alone that they are in on it. They cannot even see it when it is clearly and explicitly pointed out. It is _that_ good. It is the _primordial_ evil conspiracy; the one to which all the rest ultimately filter up, and to which they owe their existence. Every act of unkindness you've ever perpetrated on anyone; all the hardness you carry in your heart; has only ever been in its service. The evil conspiracy really exists, and (nearly) every one of us is secretly in on it. It is our refusal to acknowledge this that keeps it alive.

The only way to fight it is to stop playing its sordid game and remember a power that you have that is _far greater_.

---

The Light is not just a myth; it is your most fundamental nature. Whereas your devil is extrinsic, your compassion is _intrinsic._ It is the very root of who and what you are. When you discover this in its entirety, you see it in everyone else, too — because, after all, they _are_ you. It is your most sacred duty as a human to remember this, so that you can share it freely with others (though paradoxically, if you still see them as "other," and yourself as their noble savior, then this isn't quite it).

Your compassion is not weak — indeed, it is the most powerful force there is. It is the _only_ thing that can genuinely dispel evil, for precisely the same reason that light is the only thing that can dispel darkness: the latter is nothing but the _absence_ of the former. Yet treating it like a presence can be skillful, because then you will not underestimate its terrifying capacity to grip minds and bring the whole world to its knees. This compassion must be paired with _wisdom,_ which is the knowledge of how best to put it into fierce and uncompromising practice. That takes time to develop, and is beyond the scope of this piece. It is only with great wisdom that one can evict the darkness from the most infected of minds without getting sucked in oneself.

Such compassion may look nothing like "compassion" in the conventional sense. It can look like mocking or shaming, violence, or even _apparent_ contempt. Almost nothing is off-limits. Yet it has the opposite effect of the same actions undertaken with contempt. Two behaviors that look nearly identical on the surface can thus have dramatically different long-term effects; one sending ripples of darkness into the world, and the other of Light. Please forgive the poetic expression; I don't know how else to put it. But it is something you can discover concretely. The darkness preys on our inability to distinguish the two, which is how it convinces us that our intentions don't matter, that compassion is weak, and that contempt is righteous.

Our enemy is never truly other people, but the darkness that has overtaken all of our minds. May we learn to see this clearly, and free this world of the illusion that has overtaken it. May we remember our Light.
